reviewText:
Evolve is a disappointment, and I don't say that because the game is a catastrophe, quite the opposite, the game is a disappointment because so much effort was put into making a game that could be so much better; I'm writing this review a little more than a month into 2016 and the community was on life support well over 6 months ago. I'm going to start off with what's great about the game:

-It's easy to learn, but there's room for mastery. This has its costs and benefits, the obvious benefit is that the game is accessible to newer players, but this isn't to disparage other games with massive skill curves, initial hurdles like that can allow for beautifully complex gameplay, but thankfully Evolve doesn't shoehorn in complexity where none is necessary or enjoyable. The monster and hunters each have a short set of weapons that fulfill unique roles, instead of a multitude of tools that are largely redundant, instead of trying to learn a massive list of rock-papers-scissors you just need to figure out how to appropriately use the tools you have.
-It's got variety. People take this for granted, but the developers actually did a great job of varying the abilities of monsters, the weapons and aesthetics of hunters, and so on. People don't complain about every hunter being the same, or having the same kind of weapon, or every monster having the exact same abilities, but you can bet they would (and rightfully so) if the devs had neglected this aspect of the game.
-Maps, and this goes back to the previous point to some extent, Evolve actually has quite a few maps- enough that you'll get tired of the gameplay before you ever get tired of the setpiece for that gameplay.
-It looks pretty good, graphics aren't a dealbreaker but I can appreciate the immense effort that went into modelling, texturing, etc. to make this game look good without requiring a super computer to run it. Just from examining the environment, equipment, wildlife, hunters, or monsters, you won't conclude that the devs cut corners, no, to reach that conclusion you'll have to actually play the game.


So, why is the game a disappointment? Two reasons: balance and community. The latter problem, the community, is not technically a problem with the game itself, but this is a multiplayer game and matchmaking can take quite some time, so I hope you've got something to do while the game looks for a match (especially if you prefer to play monster.) Balance, what's wrong with balance? Well, all of the maps are understandably somewhat small, if they were significantly larger it would essentially mean that if a monster broke line of sight long enough it'd be able to escape the hunters for the whole round, some maps however are extremely small (Broken Hill Foundry) and are nearly unwinnable for the monster- if you take Wraith whose whole build is predicated on stealth and you get stuck in a ♥♥♥♥ map like that you are screwed, sure, there's some difficult choke points for the hunters, but that doesn't really matter if you're a level 1 Wraith with no survivability and unimpressive damage dealing abilities. When I played about a year ago (less than that, but not by much) the semi-competent monsters would usually stomp pubs, but any competent team of hunters would win the vast majority of games against even competent monsters. At this point, it seems like any team of pubs can just stomp the monster, at least the Wraith at this point which has been nerfed quite significantly since I last played. This is ridiculous considering the fact that competent hunters were already favored in a head to head match, because if they used their abilities like sound spikes and sending track darts into prey the monster will likely eat there's no chance the monster can sneak around until they get to max strength like I sometimes used to get away with. Maybe the players are much better now (certainly doesn't seem that way,) but I think monsters have been nerfed into the ground, the basic reasoning by the devs being that it's better to have 4 medicore players hunting the monster leave satisfied than to have 1 competent monster beat out 4 mediocre hunters who can't work together. I think the problem with the devs attempts at balancing is they base their attempts at balancing off of win rates and statistics, but not from actually watching gameplay. If competent hunters beat competent monsters 80% of the time, this would suggest to me that the game is unbalanced (hypothetically.) If comptent monsters beat incompetent teams of hunters 80% of the time, this suggests to me the obvious fact that when you have two equally powerful machines (a monster/vs a 4 man team of hunters) and the latter machine" (hunters) has 4 "moving parts" (players) that can fail
date: it stands to reason that if the game is actually balanced
recommended: the monster should win the majority of the time because it's far more likely that one of the "moving parts" is faulty in the hunter's team- yet
hoursPlayed: the devs aim towards a 50% win rate
voteText: which means they're aiming towards having monsters lose 50% of the time to a team of hunters which is 4 times more likely to contain an incompetent player- the target they consider balance will be biased against the monster because they fail to recognize that a fair match between 1 monster and 4 hunters should naturally favor the 1 monster- a monster doesn't need to worry about communicating with teammates or relying on them for success. Balancing the game off of win rates and shooting for 50% win rates will lead towards a bias against the monster
helpfulPercent: random teams of hunters that don't coordinate should not have a good chance against a competent monster. Imagine that in online chess one side consisted of one player
votesHelpful: the other of four players who were not allowed to communicate at all- the one player is naturally going to be favored; now instead imagine that the four players have the option of communicating by microphone if they plan in advance
votesTotal: even then there's a good chance one of the four players will screw it up
votesFunny: meaning that although the game is balanced the single player will win more often; this line of thinking apparently has not crossed the minds of the developers
commentsCount: or they simply do not care to examine extensive amounts of gameplay at various skill levels to get a view of game balance that is more grounded in reality.\n\nI wouldn't recommend this game unless you have 5 seriously interested friends with VERY consistent schedules
column16: otherwise this will (almost certainly) be a waste of money
column17: especially this late into the game's life."

the game is a good game, albiet still a bit buggy. the teamwork is fun, the monster is entertaining to use the idea is good. but it's just not worth $60 american to play. the majority of the game's value actually ends up coming from who you're playing with, and without good friends to play with, the whole game is boring and stale for one side and frustrating fro the other. the era of a standard game price is pretty much dead for PC games, and 2K was kind of hoping to slide this under the radar of being too much, but it simply is too much.

the bugs i mentioned are usually minor, from time to time they'll make the game unplayable, and 2K's current fix is for you to restart the game. i'm hoping they fix that (read: an actual update, none of that hotfix nonsense they love and only sometimes works) but a few of the bugs (monsters falling through the ground) suggest they simply don't care so long as the game got out.

i don't want to steer people away from this game, but i have to, simply because you aren't getting a $60 game out of this, you're getting a $40-50 game with a premium paid on it because 2K feels they're a big publisher and deserve more from you, the player. the day one DLC they stripped out of the game is greedy as well, but unneded and honestly i could care less at the point i realized the game costs too much to start with.

reviewText:
I got the PC Monster Race edition for half the cost, and I've been beating up monsters with my friends, or getting beaten up as the monster while running away crying frantically by people with their friends. This game is really solid all around.

The hunter classes are all great, and do a great job to contribute teamwork if played correctly. The three hunters for each class that the base game gives you are all pretty unique on how they work so changing up your technique with your team has options. The three monsters (Goliath, Kraken, and Wraith) you get are all very challenging, and that's one of the best features this game has.

If you can play the monster right, you can wreck face all the time, but if the team of hunters can cooperate effectively they can turn the tides easily at the start, or put up a fight towards the end. THIS GAME REQUIRES PLENTY OF COOPERATION BETWEEN HUNTERS TO TRULY ENJOY YOUR EXPERIENCE PLAYING THIS GAME AS A HUNTER. A lot of games say this, but this one really takes the cake. You just can't have two hunters on one side of the map, and the other two split up doing their own thing. You will get ♥♥♥♥ on. Do yourself a favor, and try to get some friends to play this game with. Playing solo can be underwhelming due to not having anyone to really communicate with if you're playing as a hunter, but of course you might just get into a lobby where people communicate. Try, and stick with 'em! If you like playing as the monster, by all mean, go solo.

Other nice stuff are the graphics, audio, and its tight gameplay. The graphics are pretty damn good, and they don't break my computer. I'd say you can get a smooth 60fps on high to very high settings on mid to high end computers. I'm not entirely sure on this, but I've heard this from others, and their rigs. The audio for this game is pretty spot on. Wildlife animals, monsters, and the atmosphere of Shear really bring this game to life. The hunters voice acting is also damn good. They did a good job making all of 'em unique with different accents, personality traits, and unique dialogue between one another. Gameplay controls are pretty standard for FPS players. You'll pick 'em up pretty easy like most FPS games, and the mechanics of the game very fitting.

Now why am I not recommending this game?! It's honestly because if I didn't get the PC Monster Race for half the cost, I would not have got this game. The direction 2K & TRS are taking this game in terms of DLC & pricing is absolutely ♥♥♥♥ing bonkers. They are gonna charge people 60 bucks for a game with two game modes, a handful of hunters and three monsters? They are gonna charge people a hunting season pass for 25 bucks that only has 4 of the 6 upcoming hunters you got planned out? So, wait a minute.

60 (base game) +25 (season pass) +15 (monster) +15 (monster) +7.50 (hunter) + 7.50 (hunter) = 130

There is already 70 bucks worth of content priced out as DLC right off the bat on release not adding the cosmetic shop. That's some kind of ♥♥♥♥. I can really understand all the hate the game is getting due to this business practice. You just don't get anywhere near the amount of content for 60 bucks off the base game. If this game was around the 40 buck area it would be way more appealing to everyone, but it isn't. It's simple; buy the base game for 60, and you will be left out later on if you play this game a lot, or buy the PC Monster Race edition for 100, and be set for the current stated content. It's a super ♥♥♥♥♥♥ move that will hurt the future appeal of this game. But I guess since 2K did this with Borderlands 2 (not as extreme though), and games like PAYDAY 2 can get away with it without a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ brewing, they'll try it out.

It really is a great game, and I'm having a blast playing it, but what 2K & TRS are asking from its audience is too much. If the cost is ridiculous, and it's turning you away. It's understandable, but if you really wanna buy it & play it. Wait for a Steam sale, a definitive/complete/GOTY/whatever version with all the content, or search the internet for good deals like GMG, ♥♥♥, or something. But if none of this bothers you, and you wanna pick it up. You'll have fun once you're in.

TL:DR~

Pros:
+ Paid half the cost for PC Monster Race edition (pro for me at least)
+ Solid gameplay
+ Great controls
+ Graphics are great
+ Audio & dialogue are spot on
+ Monsters are terrifying
+ Hunters are badass

Cons:
- Two game modes, very limited
- Playing by yourself can get boring (unless you like playing as the monster)
- DLC
- DLC
- DLC
- DLC
- DLC
- and DLC

Game is seriously fun playing with friends. Looks, sounds, plays, and feels great. The pricing for DLC is ridiculous. Try and get it cheap elsewhere, or wait for a sale.

7/10

Happy hunting, or not.

reviewText:
This game is supposed to be finished, but it's broken. Another example of AAA titles coming out unfinished.
Matchmaking doesn't work right: party members get dropped for no reason, and the load times are ridiculous.
The characters are imbalanced: If you've played this game for 30 seconds, you'll know that the Wraith is so overpowered. Any idiot with a keyboard can win as Wraith. It takes no talent to win, and makes the game inherently less fun.
The player progression is unbelievably huge: It takes so much time to level a character, for not much reward.
No content: not a lot of maps, not very many characters, no new weapons, and little to no variation in game modes.
Honestly, I bought this game because it had Turtle Rock's name on it. That's the last time I make that mistake.

Visually it's alright though..."

reviewText:
Despite the high quality of the graphics, which on its own is not a rare commodity these days, the game feels out of balance. It seems that if one plays as a hunter, it is impossible to get away from the attacking monster. You get a few seconds of jet fuel before it runs out, and when it does, you are done, unless tour team is willing to spend all their time healing and protecting you, which is never the case. It is understandable, that the game is about team effort, but it is extreme. However, the biggest problem I have with this game is that the movements / controls feel slow and clunky. Some may blame it on outdated hardware, but that simply is not the case.

The price is worth mentioning too. For what the game offers, it is grossly overpriced, to the level of absurdity. That must be the business plan, to sell season passes and DLCs.

I am very disappointed, put shortly.

reviewText:
Before I get any flack for the negative rating, let me just say that this is my personal experience and my opinion as of right now. It could change to positive depending on if the issues are fixed or not.

Right now, it seems the optimization for this game is beyond decent. No matter what settings I use, you get the same 25-45 FPS in game. The FPS issues are not unique to me, I am not sure why this is.

There is also a bug that makes you spawn outside or under the map at times.

Until the game is better optimized and has some of the issues and bugs ironed out, I can't recommend this right now. Totally unplayable in my experience. However, if you are someone who can handle frames below 60 or you're one of the lucky people who are somehow able to run this game at 60FPS and above, then be my guest.

reviewText: There are two positive things worth saying about this otherwise atrocious game. First, it has potential. Second, there are moments when it is very fun and exciting.\n\nNevertheless do not buy this game. It is not worth $60, as there is almost no content, and after a few rounds its overly repetitive. Moreover, the little content that is included is extremely buggy. For instance, several of my friends had their sound cutting on and off during combat. Randomly your mouse cursor will appear on the screen, which is not in line with your centered cross hairs, making aiming and navigation confusing and difficult. There are at least a half dozen loading screens before a game starts, many of which just seem superfluous and unnecessary. Oftentimes one player will get stuck between loading screens while everyone else moves onto the next one, requiring you to either abort the player or restart the game. Randomly a friend will get booted from a game, when their internet service is working fine. Overall, this is an unfinished game, that should not have been released. But even if it WAS finished, it does not contain $60 worth of content at all. Not to mention there is $130 worth of DLC, which should be included in the game as is, since the game itself is not complete, functioning well, nor does it contain close to $60 worth of stuff. Overall, total scam and rip off. Don't buy it. I would return it if I could.

reviewText:
A great game, lots of fun. I really enjoy the teamwork and playing as the monster gets your heart pounding as you carefully plan your attack or just go barging in. The graphics are great, the maps are well though out... it's a truly good game.

So why do you not recommend it you ask.

Well, the reason that I don't recommend buying it is because you are not buying a full game for £34.99, oh no! you are buying a piece of the game for that price and if you want to play the full game you are forced to buy it piece by piece as DLC. That really makes me angry, if you want the full game you will have to fork out a ridiculous £58.99 and then have the honour of buying 'skins' to add insult to injury. I had faith in the developers so preordered the game so I got some extras, since the release though and the overly priced dlc packages I wish I hadn't. Just plain GREED!

reviewText:
Evolve Review
Evolve is a 4v1 game where you can either play as a hunter or as a Monster. Monster needs to kill all hunters or destroy Power Relay in order to win the game. Hunter's need to kill the monster in order to win the game. Gameplay might seem familiar to some people who have played Nosgoth" or "Primal Carnage" which also have similar concept.


Hunters
Hunter's have four classes
date: each class has multiple characters with different playstyles:\n\nMedic Heals teammates
recommended: Slows and marks the Monster. Hitting the marked points using assault weapon results in huge damage.\n\nAssaulter Main damage dealer. Has weapons like rifle
hoursPlayed: flamethrower etc. with utility abilities like grenades and mines and a self shield.\n\nTrapper Traps the monster within a certain radius and helps tracking the monster using pet
voteText: sound trackers etc. Also has an ability to pin the monster in place for a short time.\n\nSupportNegats the damage done to allies
helpfulPercent:
Stealths allies and has the ability to Air Strike the monster dealing huge damage.


Monsters
There are currently three monsters in  the game Goliath
votesHelpful:
Wraith and Kraken both having different playstyles.
General gameplay of the monster:

- Relies on stealth early because of weaker early game.
- Requires feeding on neutral monsters in order to get stronger to face the Hunters in an upfront battle.
- Once reaches level 3 can steamroll the hunters 1v4 or destroy the power relay to win the game.


GOLIATH
Melee  monster who destroys hunters 1v4 once level 3. Fun to play once you learn to use the stealth and feeding to level up. Weak at level 1
votesTotal:
Too hard to take down once it hits level 3 so patience and stealth is the key early game. Never won a game against a level 3 Goliath or lost a game as a level 3 Goliath.


KRAKEN
Ranged monster with sniping abilities and can destroy hunter level 1. (Needs balancing) Fun to play with skillshot abilities and brings in a totally different playstyle. Needs to be nerfed and should have lower health/armor compared to Goliath.

WRAITH
Wraith is the stealthy assassin. She’s a space alien Monster who warps around the battlefield
votesFunny: ripping into her enemies with her blade-claws. She can hit – then run – before you even see her coming.\nThe Wraith has considerably less health and armour than other monsters but makes up for it in agility and surprise element
commentsCount:
favoring a stealthy gameplay style.


Positives
- Hunter classes are fun to play and evolves as you gain experience with different characters unlocking with each class.
- Fun to play as the monster and destroy faces 1v4 after levelling up.
- Nicely designed map.
- Amazing monster design.
- Good sense of progression as you put in hours.
- Competitive gameplay since co-ordination is required at a very high level.

Negatives
- Some hunters are totally useless against certain monsters. For example: Maggie's traps are useless against Kraken.
-Pay to win inclined model since you must have certain hunters in order to deal with a particular monster and new Hunters are shipped as purchasable DLCs.
- Balancing issues. (cant complain due to Alpha)
- Monsters are hard to play compared to Hunters in terms of overall effort required.
- Sometimes you have nothing to do as a hunter if Monster is playing super stealth mode
column16:
need more activities for Hunters.


Beta Changes
-New Game modes.
-Kraken got nerfed but still pretty strong mainly because you need certain Hunters to counter his a ss.
-Improved Performance.
-New Hunters and a new monster. (Only available to pre-purchasers right now)"

column46: the game is visually stunning and very immersive. Gunplay is fun and satisfying. Good Monster players can make the Monster role seem insanely easy. Playing your role effectively will give you tense moments of action and fun

as it can spam the decoy ability too effectively whilst taking no damage and delivering full damage to Hunters, not only that, but any HUD icon signaling the monsters whereabouts that the Trapper placed on it with Griffin or Abe is directly on the Decoy. However, the Monster is the most important player in the game being that unskilled players won't even make it fun for the Hunters.

MONSTER: This needs it's own section because I can't compliment the monsters voice acting or background. I must say it is very worthwhile to go hard out into the role of monster. Stealthing isn't the only way to eliminate Hunters, rather than stealth I prefer to leave my tracks deliberately, going right through dens of hostile wildlife and jumping over rivers with Tyrants (Alien Alligators) sitting at the bottom, without a competent Medic or Trapper as I stated above, as the Monster you will absolutely stomp the Hunters. knowing how to outrun and trick the Hunters is key, at one point without even engaging them until stage 3; I killed two hunters with two Tyrants. Daisy is like a pumpil on your butt and makes Monster challenging, as she will make sure to avoid you and not plunge herself into danger to revive teammates, you will find Hunters using every strike they have after you stomp the Trapper and Medic.

Val is a solid 10/10; absolutely delicous, Markov is a tough 7/10; but the vodka adds nice flavor to the meat, I am a fan of delicous dark meat Maggie with a Daisy side was a good 8/10, Hank's beard gets stuck in your teeth; 5/10.

The Wraith, is an absolute badass; between it's stalking and strategic attacks, it's a serious change of pace from the Goliath, the most accurate way to sum it up is it's basically a floating ninja that teleports. My very first game as Wraith was way easier then the Goliath or the Kraken, rather then accurate ranged attacks or just rampaging through a hail of gunfire you instead trick the hunters into leaving a huge opening. I did so using a decoy while attacking the relay, my decoy went left after the lone support, the Hunters grouped up on the opposite side of the room firing at it, the Support jetpack dodged into his team, one supernova attack forcing them into the corner, and they all died at the same time. I win.

Matchmaking system matches new players with veterans

reviewText:
Regardless of where you fall on the DLC/weapon skins/pre-order shenanigans, there's actually an alarming number of customers, myself included, that are having severe performance issues with this game.

Just a few random threads from the first couple pages in the forum:

http://steamcommunity.com/app/273350/discussions/0/611698195145237313/
http://steamcommunity.com/app/273350/discussions/0/606068060839572340/
http://steamcommunity.com/app/273350/discussions/0/611698195145553312/
http://steamcommunity.com/app/273350/discussions/0/611698195145502022/

My system can run most modern processor-heavy games like Dying Light, Shadow of Mordor, and Alien: Isolation with everything set to at least High, but even with everything set to low and AA turned off, this game chugs. I can muscle through the first level of Evacuation, but without fail the second level becomes a complete sideshow.

More telling than the framerate is that the menus also stop completely for large chunks of time. You'd be forgiven for thnking the game had crashed, but then a minute later it proceeds. That means the performance issues go much deeper than your typical poorly optimized title.

It's not just that AAA games release utterly broken more often than not these days, but what's the point of a prolonged Alpha and Beta if you're not going to fix known issues and release an unfinished game anyway? That sort of activity makes you wonder what kind of post-launch support we can expect. They seem to have emphasized microtransactions over technical stability.

Completely unacceptable, and more than a little disappointing given I was actually looking forward to this game quite a bit. Whether you pay $60 or $160, you're rolling the dice with this one.

Mediocre game lacking content that was probably moved away from the game and added as day 1 DLC content. I like to support developers for the hard work they put in and the time it takes, but when they charge needlessly for extra content (DLC's)  that otherwise should have been ingame already, they are basically stealing away from loyal legitimate users which is no different from pirates ripping them off.

Turtle Rock may want to review their buisness practices and 2k should be ashamed of themselves, though i'm sure in the short term this worked out for them but long term might be a different story. Whenever you crap on customers, on your doorstep with questionable Day 1 DLC that is painfully obvious should have been included into the base game it's going to be hard to clean that up and customers will be less willing to put trust in your future products.

If you've not purchased the game, I would highly recommened that you wait till the pricing has come down if you really want to try this out which I'm sure will happen within a  month or two.

reviewText:
predetermine EOL (End of Life) 02/09/15 EVOLvE is a diamond. Its asymetrical gameplay shines through the borring world of Multiplayer FPS these days.
It is polished fine product with marketing decisions gone wrong the possibly worst way!

At a pricetag of striking 79,99€ you still don't own the full game.
Just to clear this out. This game
is not a part of the Call of Duty franchise
is custom-tailored to please players for asymetric teambased combat vs one player only
is an experimental subgenre of FPS
has lesser content than these free to playgames: Dota2/LOL/Smite, so on so forth..Why in gods name do you make such a business desicion and add this price onto an experimental game like this.
The userbase for this kind of game is super small to start with. And if I was representitive for your avg. gamer I will think twice spending my hard earned money on such an entryprice tag knowing that I am missing out content still.

I was so proud to test this game in alpha and beta stages, and I kind of enjoyed it for what it was. But adding Day One DLC to it and justify the price with an higher workload of balancing out the game - NOPE.

Games that deserve the mark of beeing top notch balanced are MOBAs with their bazillion characters, skilltrees and item posibilities. 2k obviously wasn't sure about how they going to fit into the market with this product and gave it that overpriced badge to make sure the once who bought it on launch will pay up for their upfront investments into EVOLvEs production.

You may get my money when this game turns up for like € 29,99 as a GoTY with everything in it. But at this time the game as could be considered dead. Who want's to fight the same guys over and over again...

reviewText:
So it seems like 2K want to be the new E.A with their microtransactions.

In British money, if you want all of the games content on the day of release, that'll be £105 good sir.

Let's not forget that when you install the game before even buying the DLC, all of the DLC's content is installed with the game, so what you're actually doing is paying money for something you already actually have.

It's Mass Effect 2 all over again!

Only a boneheaded idiot with dollar signs for eyes would think this marketing plan was a good idea, and given the amount of negative reviews I'm sure you all can see here, one that is going to cost 2K a LOT of reputation, and let's face it, when they shut down the studio that developed Bioshock games, they already lost a lot of reputation.

So hey 2K, you should use all your ill-gotten gains to go buy yourself a bigger shovel 'cos you need to dig yourself a deeper hole!

Now on to explaining the game...

Evolve is... in the best way I can explain, boring.  Boring boring boring boring boring.
Either you're a human and you hunt a monster, and succeeding in killing it wins the match, or you play as a monster and... probably get killed by the humans.  That's about it.  Yes there's a few different kinds of maps and yes the humans and monsters all have different types of skills but really all you'll ever do is the same thing over and over and over again, it gets dull extremely quickly and why this game was so hyped up when it's so incredibly basic a concept I'll never know.
To draw a comparison to give you an idea.  Imagine Left 4 Dead, now remove all of the zombies and other monsters and leave just the Tank.  Evolve is 4 survivors versus a tank, that's it, when the tank dies the humans win, if the tank kills the survivors or destroys a building (should he somehow manage to level himself up before the humans find him), the tank wins.  Ok, now rinse and repeat that same process hundreds of times, sound like fun?  No?

Don't buy this crap.

and what's worse is that the underhanded business is going to scare people off and make the player base smaller, so matches will be harder to find, etc.

bottom line, this game is a massive ripoff at 60$, with the amount they're asking us to pay to unlock things it really should be free to play.

reviewText:
NOTICE: I see that my total playtime for Evolve is listed as 0.0. This is an error, I am not sure why it has occurred. I played the game for approximately 6-8 hours before I wrote this review.


Evolve is a pretty simple game, at its core. You and three other hunters team up to defeat an enormous monster controlled by a fifth player. Or, you control the monster yourself, starting off relatively weak but through eating local wildlife and staying out of the hunters’ path, you evolve to two more powerful stages. Reach the third one, and you become a nigh unstoppable killing machine. Though there are multiple game modes and each of the four hunter classes have three different characters with a unique loadout, every round of the game plays pretty much exactly the same. And that’s where the problems start to pile up. You see, Evolve is a bare bones experience to put it mildly. There are only a few maps, and all play the same. There are only two modes of play. The main mode is Hunt, which has the hunters searching for the monster which tries to evolve to a powerful enough stage so that it can kill the hunters or destroy an important building. And then there’s the “campaign” mode called Evacuation, which is five random matches loosely tied together by some well-produced but hollow and meaningless cinematics. The matches themselves are played in three different game modes - all of which are slight modifications to the Hunt-mode, all playing the same.

After some time, you’ll come to realize that you had seen the entire game already within the first few hours of play. Sure, playing with a different hunter or monster gives you other abilities, but you still do the exact same thing every match; escape and evolve as the monster, search and hunt as the hunter. And the way you do it isn’t even altered either. Every match either ends within a couple of minutes in which the monster player is trapped and killed early - and likely rage-quits as a result - or the monster eventually reaches stage three. By this point, the hunters have been running around the entire map for fifteen minutes, uneventfully sniffing at tracks and looking at birds. It might sound like some sort of intense “quiet before the storm” build-up, but it really only is exciting like that the first few rounds. After that, the distinct feeling of monotony sets in. Evolve is extremely repetitive, and the flawed progression system that’s supposed to have you coming back for more, does a ♥♥♥♥ poor job at doing so. It even goes so far as to force players to use ineffective methods that can lead to a match loss, just so that you can level up and unlock the next character for a class. And if you don’t have any friends who play the game - or God forbid, you live in Europe where nobody uses voice chat in public play - then you are out of luck. Playing Evolve will feel like playing the lottery. You’ll rarely find a match where people talk in a friendly manner, work together and try to enjoy the game without ruining everybody else’s day.

Evolve is, if anything, a solid backbone to what could’ve been an amazing game. Evolve would have been an amazing free-to-play shooter. The groundwork is there, and it’s solid. The controls are responsive and the mechanics are streamlined to the max. It’s a concept that is clearly thought out, and apart from a few frustrating bugs and balancing issues, the overall impression is extremely polished. But with the lackluster amount of content that you get for the asking price, the inherent monotony of the gameplay and the downright offensive DLC strategy that asks $15 - the equivalent of an overpriced map pack - just for a single new monster-character, I doubt that a couple of paid DLCs offering new monsters and hunters will be enough to keep the player count strong for more than a couple of months at best. And that is just sad because it’s evident that the developers knew what they were doing, but it seems the publisher got in their way at every junction. Cut this out, save it for later. DLC this, DLC that. When you pay this much from the get-go, and then are expected to keep paying in order to actually get a slight semblance of variety out of the damn thing, then it honestly isn’t worth it in my book. If you’re going to get Evolve, then get it cheap. Very cheap. And because there aren’t any dedicated servers, you’ll be wise to check if the game actually has an actively playing community at all when you first decide to plunk down the dough.

reviewText:
Very fun game with lots of potential but the amount of content for the price of the game is not worth it.
I would've bought the game when i heard there's more content coming but I dislike the idea of having to pay even more for the content. Yes, I know there's season pass to get everything without ever paying again but I think it's as cheap system as the bonus points all kinds of stores give you when you spend ridiculous amount of money in a year just to get 50€ bonus (all of you who live in on your own know how it's close to impossible to ever get bonus that high).
I rather pay 80 for this game and get more content free than pay 50€ now and then pay for every content released later.
As fun as this game is, unless you like repeatitive games like CS, CoD, BF multiplayers, you get tired of it no matter how much classes and monsters is added.
In short: The devs made awesome game that currently lacks content and the way they are selling it is a big no for me.
I only recommend it for people who loves to climb leaderboards and have no issues of doing the same thing over and over again to get to the top like i.e. Diablo, CS, Dota and WoW.
I do not recommend it for people who dislike grinding.
Lastly: the unlocking of new classes is ok but the way you unlock the encourages players to tryhard" in one specific way to get them fast which might lead them to being harmful for the teamplay in example: Trap monster X amount of times inside the dome
recommended: then releasing the dome right away to prevent monster from dying and then going after it once the cooldown has refreshed."

reviewText:
It's hard to describe my disappointment with this game. Good game if you maybe are lucky enough to have a team of people you know in real life. Extremely unbalanced despite what every official review says. I have yet to lose a match to a monster when I have 3 human teammates, no matter the handicap on evac. I also have yet to win as the monster against 4 human controlled hunters, again despite the handicap. The maps are too small. Being the moster is boring and sadly lonely. There are a ton of little things missing that most any dev should have been able to do, 2 examples being:
Can't play a custom match with only 1 friend and still chose bots
Extremely hard to just quickly look at your character progression goals from any screen other than after match reports

Again, would be an amazing party/lan game if you had enough people to fill the slots. Would also be a great game if I didn't have a life so I could build up a friend list of people I've only met online who play this game so I wouldn't have to Q alone and be the monster 99% of the time in online PvP. But unfortunately, I have to work and stuff.

Lastly, I agree with everyone, the pricing for this game sucks. There isn't as much game as they try to make it sound like with their whole every mission is slightly different" BS. Also
date: the DLC hunters that just released are crazy OP right now while the DLC Monster is not very good at all.\n\nIt was a good attempt."

reviewText:
Evolve (Just the base game, not the DLC, not the season pass) is a fun game for myself. I enjoy the game modes that they  implemented into the game (Hunt, Rescue, Nest, & Defend) and then Evacuation (combining the 4 modes into an interesting 'plot' over 5 days). The 12 hunters all have their own personality and kits/weapon loadouts making each of their gameplay different from the other (from Markov and his lightning gun to Parnell with his rapid fire shotgun). There are all sorts of playstyles mixing up the hunters. A fun game in my opinion though I do not know if I would charge $60 for a multiplayer only game (yes even the 'solo' campaign mode is the same as multiplayer, just with bots instead of other players). I felt thats the bots both fellow hunter bots and the monster bot are really well done in the game (though they can bug out occasionally). The game maps are interesting though some feel a bit simialr to others, though all in all the 12 different maps make for interesting and varying gameplay. To add onto the game, future maps and game mode will be free, making the base game amazing


Now for the cons. While the game itself is fun, there are some parts of the game, or parts to be added that drag it down. The first would be the three ways of obtaining the game. A flat $60 for Evolve, the $80 delux edition, and the $100 PC Monster race all three do not include the day one DLC. Given it is JUST COSMETIC, so it isn't that big of a loss though trying to sell the season pass or the 100 dollar order without the added DLC leaves a few questions to be asked. On top of the DLC, future monsters as well as hunters will be an added cost so while the player gets new maps and modes, the new characters are locked less you pay. Given they are fun, Hunt, Rescue, Nest & Defend get stale after a while.

All in all, if you can find the game with everything included (all they have to offer in one package) then jump all over it. Outside of that, either just get the game and enjoy it for what it is and try to ignore 2K trying to sell you DLC which merits the negative review

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wWJ77J3Zf68&

Alright this is coming from someone with extensive experience from the alpha to release, who has held numerous #1-#10 placements across some monsters and hunters, do not pay attention to the recommend and the not recommend because I am indifferent to the game. I will not using pitiful excuses you're seeing on most reviews either and will be straightforwards.

This game is certainly not worth £35, but I trust you know how to axe £10 off of that, winkwink, then I would argue that it is, but spending cash is partially relative to the customer. There is no reason to buy any other variations of the game that promise things such as unlocked hunters given that all unlockables are incredibly easy to achieve, and can be done against bots/solo. You have a right to be ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off at the idea that there is going to be another monster that MUST be purchased, and is not unlockable. (Obviously, these bundles are more expensive too, but essentially offer, nothing).

Currently there are severe balancing issues with the Wraith, who still keeps a skewered win rate, who I trust will be nerfed to the ground, (6 second decoy with 50% cooldown reduction, it's a smart idea I swear, lets put it on a mammoth bird, not a sloth, lets put it on something that dies in two hits) but the Goliath and Kraken are balanced additions to the game. As are the majority of hunters. However, certain hunters dramatically outperform others.

For example, Abe can track the monster nearly indefinately with correct movement and a near guarentee trap if he pays
attention to the map and monster movement, as well as stasis grenades that ground the kraken and severely slow monsters. He diminishes Val and Bucket.

Furthermore, with characters like Lazarus, Bucket, or Hyde on the team, the monster has a near certified win if performed correctly,

-Lazarus's healing ability is pathetic, he has a niche role to ressurect the dead, a dead anything should not be happening in the first place, it's like losing your legs to attach a gun to your forehead. You make sure things do not die, period. You place yourself, as Lazarus, in a position where you can get singled out and destroyed in a matter of seconds because you have to approach a corpse which the monster knows is there, and seeing how you shimmer, leave footprints, and leave jet smoke, you're hardly invisible are you?

-Bucket is by far the most useless character in the game with a gimmicky turret system, all of which break with ease or unintentionally under hails of AoE and smashing, he provides zero support aspects to the team, and his UAV is outclassed by Abe's tracking. Hank and Cabot genuinely provide support by buffing the team, even Caira does this and she's the ♥♥♥♥ing medic. Hank is especially good seeing how you can provide a shield to someone in distress, and wipe over 1/3 of a monsters health with a splendid airstrike combined with stasis/tranq/harpoon/cabot's damage boost.

-As for Hyde, he's more 'in your face' then the rest of the assaults, whilst Markov can safely pick away with his L.gun and has access to mines that do impressive damage, making him useful in all modes, and Parnell's ability to not only deal good damage from far away, but skyrocket his damage with the S.gun + rage combo, Hyde is left in the dust, he can only huge a goliath with a flamer and get torn to pieces.

If you are not concerned with balance or other semantics, you just wanna buy a game and shoot a monster and be a big monster, go nuts, seriously, because it's exactly that, but it certainly isn't worth the price on Steam.

TL;DR I recommend you wait for a few months before trying this, the price will go down if you're getting this on Steam (why) and things will be more balanced.

EDIT: I will further add that the line of This is the complete game with things you can choose to buy" with "You get the entire game if you pay more money" is very
date: very thin and suspicous with this
recommended: especially considering you must pay for a monster that is not far from launch."

reviewText:
Evolve is the great example how to turn good idea for game (and actually pretty fun game that we were shown on 1st alpha tests) into ♥♥♥♥, boring, cashgrabing DLC bay.

Pros:
+ Graphic

Cons:
- DLC bay, it feels like when they saw how many people bought game to participate in 1st alpha tests they decided to make as much cash as possible out of it increasing price, adding ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of paid dlcs etc,. Just the way EA do with battlefield series, forget this game if you dont plan to buy dlcs for it,
- Gameplay is booooring, The game was advertised as unique since everytime you deploy shield in different place, making every fight different and intresting, the truth is Evolved game is fun for 2 days, than you need at least 1 month break from it to find it any fun again
- ♥♥♥♥ lvling system that makes you use useless abilities or for example follow dog for xxxxxx km just to unlock next character. Doing this things dont help your team at all making you useless member of the team.
- No option to join game lobby makes you join 70% of the time matches that are already on with character that ragequitter had.
- Abilities that were fun and important to use during alpha were nerfed or made useless just to encourage people to buy overpowered dlc characters

Watching steam charts its obvious this game is already dead (less players than any other crap games) and as long as devs wont change their minds for game and buisness model i dont think there is any good reason to buy this game anymore

reviewText:
This game certainly isn't for everyone. I myself found Evolve rather enjoyable. The characters were well thought out and all had their own unique personalities, the monster is a ton of fun to play if you know what you're doing, and the game does offer a lot of replayability.

However, I'm loosing faith in this game very quickly. After almost a week after the game's release, some major bugs still haven't been fixed yet (ex. the mouse still showing up on screen). On top of that, there is still no news of upcoming updates or future content other than the Behemoth.

I love this game, I really do. But due to the current price of the game and the overabundance of non-existent dlc it is offering, I simply cannot recommend it. If you are interested in playing it, wait until it goes on sale or when a little more content is added.

reviewText: When I first saw this game I became excited and thrilled. When I started my first game I was shaking. When I had my first encounter with the monster I became distraught. I did everything I could as a trapper to keep the beast down. Placed a perfect dome multiple harpoon traps as magie and multiple shots with the harpoon gun as Griffin. Although i succeeded with Griffin to keep a monster from jumping away. All the monster needed to do was melee the harpoon cable off (makes sense) then countinued jumping. I was reloading my harpoon and when i was ready for another shot the monster is on the other side of the map (litterally). This game is beyond one sided (in favor to the monsters). Hunters helplessly chase down monsters with no sprinting abilities and a jetback with a horrible recharge rate and jumping (do not even try to dodge a massive aoe knockback from a monster will hit you any way). In the few games I have won with hunters were lucky wins. I was lucky that the monster didnt even try to eat and fought the team at stage one (still downed two people). Won a defense game barely with generator close to being one hit away from destruction (The monster entered the lobby and said They need to make this mode easier".). Do not get me started on the Wraith. Caught the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ SIX times in the fight but the ability to go invisible for the duration of the dome is beyond any logic."

reviewText:
So You see the mixed user review and your wondering should I buy this game?

Well in all honesty I cannot blame the mixed reviews, if the gaming industry wanted to find out exactly how to almost ruin a games chances of success....2k can write the bloody book and direct the film!

Its actually heart breaking...the game is fun to play, lots of fun actually. A little bit linear perhaps but plays in a similar vein to L4D2, in that the game play will always be fun. You can re-visit it time after time and still be laughing. Below is some footage i recorded and in my actual game at the end...well you can see how much fun I'm having - thats all genuine.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hSGVKoCtKSY

But...and yes there is a but, a huge one! The price tag and the funky weird approach to DLC.Is it worth the price tag? Honestly check the video and judge for yourself, its only from a monster perspective but it gives you a clearer idea of whats involved in the game and of course the adrenaline that comes with it.

However regardless of that, the game is fairly limited, there is a lot of character progression to work through in both monster side and hunter side, but its the same maps essentially with bigger guns and more damage. Sadly of course some of this is lost because you imrprove as you level...but you get matched with people at a similar level, who have the same perks so your not actually any further ahead. And lets be honest, everybody loves an advantage!

I am still recommending the game...but as hard as it is for me to say this, wait until it drops a little. I also feel there is room for more and may well be future content added (10v2 anyone??)

reviewText:
the game itself is superb as a starting point.

there is too little content to be justified for being 60$-70$

the level is good the gunplay is great everything about the game is great but thats what worries me. the game needs more content, it needs alot more content. a few new maps and monsters wont change the fact that the game isnt fun after a couple hours, if they want this to be worth 60$+ they need to make some major changes.

if i need to compare this to another co-op game id have to say PAYDAY 2 because they are both 2 co-op games that give you 1 objective and ask you to solve it. but unlike payday 2 where there is tension and the ability to feel like you are actually in a bank robbery, here you just run arround with your jetpack which drains too fast and its cooldown is too long looking for the monster to kill it. although it can get intense when the entire team is coardanated and interacting with each other - meaning if you want to get really imersed you need a MIC.

1 suggestionf for them is to have an epic battle mode where like 3-5 monsters go off agienst alot of soilders as it would add so much value to the game

overall if you want to play this game wait for a sale. a big one. (this is only if they dont add a ton of new content on release)

reviewText:
You'll have a blast playing the game for the first ~100hours, if not less. Once this point is reached it feels like you're playing the same game over and over.  There's little to no repeatability.
The only thing that would give you some incentive to play the game is to try out the next batch of hunters and monsters but here lies to problem. If you want to play them you have to pay. 8euros per new hunter and 15euro per new monster. And that's on top of the original price.

I was under the assumption, that has now proven to be completely false, that you could play the next set of hunters by ranking up the previous tier. I've held a long time to post a review for the game since I always hoped TRS would come to their senses and sort out this marketing nonsense. It appears I was wrong.

reviewText:
412 hours into the game and it's still fun. Let me address some issues I see people complaining about when they talk about Evolve:

Game price: I bought the game two weeks after launch for 22 Euros that included the 4th monster (Behemoth). If you buy games off Steam at launch and complain about prices, you aren't doing it right. Brick and mortar shops are still cheaper (at least in EU) and game code websites will probably give you the best prices. Learn to find good deals people.

DLC: There are only two real DLCs - 4 additional Hunters and the 4th monster (the latter you can get for 2 euros more when you buy the Monster edition of the game). They aren't pay to win, other Hunters are at least just as good, if not better and Behemoth is by far the weakest monster in the game right now. Granted, the price for the Hunters is a little steep, but other games charge for maps, instant max levels etc. All Evolve has other than those two real DLCs are skins. You don't need them to enjoy the game.

It's a running simulator": No
date: it's not. You're just playing with random groups against a good monster. Play with friends. Don't have friends who play the game? That's alright
recommended: neither did I when I started. Evolve added about 40 people to my friends list
hoursPlayed: some of who are now my best online buds I play other games with as well. Here's a simple guide for finding good players to play with: 1) Go solo with randoms 2) Listen for people using a microphone and watch how they play 3) If they're good
voteText: consider asking after the match "Hey
helpfulPercent: can I add you on Steam?". Took me no time at all to find an established group I still play with most of the time which makes the game (like any multiplayer game really) a lot more fun. Or
votesHelpful: if you like playing solo
votesTotal: play the Monster and get good at it
votesFunny: no friends or communication required.\n\nBugs/glitches: Not very many left of them in the game. Most of the big ones got sorted out very soon after launch
commentsCount: there's mostly just some minor ones left and they hardly drag the game down. Hell

but those exist in any multiplayer game and they weren't even as egregious as some of the FotMs I've seen in other games.

So what are the real issues of the game?
The issue of the game was terrible marketing. The launch was plagued by several releases of the game that made the process of buying the version with everything you wanted (if you wanted to get the new hunters

reviewText: Having no RL mates with Evolve to team up with, I was concerned about what I might encounter in pubs. Multiplayer games live and die by their community, so, to see what proportion of players were friendly and what was, er, less so, I interviewed people in a series of thirty games. What I've found makes me feel that Evolve just isn't set up to promote the teamwork necessary to make asymmetric multiplayer fun for more than a few rounds. Unless you've a good bunch of friends lined up to play with, I'd pass.\n\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_XdoY5IquCQ&list=UU4Ding5W4J7iU_lCWElylQw

reviewText: I stopped playing this game less than 2 weeks after its launch due to its bugs and unbelievable imbalance but held off on writing a negative review because I had hope that it would be patched into something playable. Also there seems to be no plan to fix the various exploits that are still rife within the game or even so much as an acknowledgement of the completely broken leader boards.\n\nForget the badly marketed DLC or the item shop, what should stop you from buying this game is the fact that it was launched broken and the developers either don't care or think they have all the time in world to fix it. reviewText:
Dem marketing strategies tho.

The game is probably one of the most fun gaming experiences I've ever had. A lot of people compare it to Left 4 Dead, but I think it's way better. Gameplay is fast and fun. Controls are decent for the most part, a few glitches here and there, but those will most likely be fixed. I guess there's a story in it, but it doesn't need one, 'There's a monster in the woods, go kill it' is good enough for me. The characters are actually well devoloped for the most part, in terms of personality and gameplay. The graphics look great, but not so great that you can't stay focused on the objective, which is neat. The monsters are also well designed, despite a few over-powered abilities that SOME monster has (  wraith ), but all in all, the teams are fairly balanced. One of it's major flaws is that it has a matchmaking system out of hell. The networking needs to be improved dramatically.

The biggest issue with this game is the price. While the game is fun as all hell, it does not have the necessary amount of content to be worth $60. It has singleplayer and multiplayer, but they're essentially the same thing. The characters are fun and interesting, but there are so few of them, and putting a pricetag on the rest of them is a bit low. Not saying it doesn't have a high replay value; it really does, but for the price it's at now, you're not getting a fair deal.

In conclusion, unless you have a lot of money and wondering where to dump it all, I wouldn't bother getting this game until the price drops significantly. It's fun as all hell, and doesn't present many gameplay issues, but it's not worth what's on the current price-tag.

Otherwise, I don't recommend this game.

reviewText:
I will start by directing your attention to my 730 hours logged.  The game is crazy fun; TRS had lightning in a bottle, and they have screwed up in every conceivable fashion.

If a game is any good, hardcore competition will Evolve naturally.  The devs tried to bill the game like this from the very start, to the detriment of the majority playerbase.  The focus on competition at the expense of casual has lead to the community as we see it today; the remaining playerbase is elitist, salty, and generally all-around jerks.

Pros:
-The characters & story are genuninely engaging and fun.  Credit where credit is due, the universe of Evolve extremely entertaining.  The official forums has a writing section where the lead writer posts canon backstory & events.

-The customization options for a match are numerous and fun, but are virtually inaccessible (see Cons).

-Hunting, the thrill of the chase.  When both Monster & Hunters have the mindset of providing a good fight (as opposed to soley winning or stomping), Hunt is adrenaline-packed good time.

-Community challenge every 2 weeks awards a skin or set thereof.  I have like 50 in total now, and never spent a dime.

Cons:
-Complete lack of options for pub matches (non-Ranked).  You can't choose map or game mode, nevermind all of the really cool map effects and other fun options (extra critters for Monster, bonus Turrets for Hunters, adjust Strikes & Timer, etc.).  These things are exclusively available in private matches (solo or with friends).

-Ranked mode is the only way to consistently play Hunt.  Again, focus on competition at the expense of everyone else.

-Most Hunter skins are literally a single color change on the weapon.  A few Hunter skins are stand-out, and Monster ones range from 'decent' to 'lulz awesome'.

Summary:
The game is dead, and has been for quite some time now.  I'm just glad I got to enjoy the ride down.  At this point, nothing can save it short of the devs acknowledging their mistakes and directly all efforts to improving public gameplay.

reviewText:
Very fun game. Even more fun when you're playing with a full party of your friends. The action is intense, and though I intend on playing this game far more, it isn't a game I can sit and play for an entire day. The graphics are beautiful, even if you can't play it maxed. Unfortunately though, a good portion of the matches you play turn into a game of chasey-chasey catchey-catchey kissy-kissy where you run around the outside of the map Benny Hill style for ten minutes until the monster finally evolves and you head for the power relay. This gets old very quick. The other side of that coin are the battles you win by the skin of your teeth that get your heart racing. These are especially enjoyable.

Now for the reason I can't recommend this game. The pricing model. Marketing the game at $100 ($120 on consoles) for full content is insulting and a massive affront to the people who were excited for it in the first place. If it were a fremium game with a cash shop to purchase additional characters or skins, I would 100% recommend this game. And if I hadn't made a promise to my friends that I would buy it when it came out (I don't preorder games. Ever.) I would not have bought it. My recommendation to you, is to wait until it inevitably goes on sale for a more fair price. A $120 price tag on an arena shooter is outrageous. Vote with your dollar (If you wish to call me a hypocrite I understand). 2K chose this pricing in fear of Evolve not generating enough revenue. Show them they're doing it wrong.

(2-14-15) I finally had an opportunity to play Evacuation, and this is actually a very fun mode. It changes up the gameplay a noticeable amount and keeps things fresh. I certainly intend on spending more time playing this mode. Some fights include Nest, where the monster starts out at stage 3 and you have to destroy it's eggs. This completely does away with the Benny Hill chase and is one of my preferred modes to play. There are also others where you have to save soldiers and bring them back to the dropship while the monster tries to kill them. Why these modes haven't been advertised as much is completely beyond me. The same Left 4 Dead tank battle" comparison is still accurate in these gamemodes
date: but to a somewhat lesser degree. Evacuation is definitely a highlight of Evolve.\n\nThere is slightly more content than I originally thought
recommended: though a $60 price tag is still questionable. My recommendation shall remain No for the time being
hoursPlayed: but it is slightly less harsh of a no. I will update this review in the future if my opinion changes but still

reviewText:
Save yourself both money and time by not purchasing this release. Don't buy into the half-a-game-plus-DLC business model. It's ridiculous that we allow developers to build a game that is functionally incomplete at day one, and charge us $60 for the intentionally limited honor. Vote with your wallet.

The company didn't even care, in their now publically regocnized mistake, to allow preorders to upgrade to the packages that were later released. Gave them money when they were griping about delays? Not only will they treat you as second-rate to second-comers, that extra time was used to make DLC. They are and will only ever be interested in minimum input to maximum profit. I'm still in shock that they delayed this game just for the purposes of shoving additional day one DLC down our throats. It's unbelievable that they would ever think it was acceptable to take our money, and use it to delay the game just to charge us more!

In the abstract the idea of the game is great, but purchasing the game and its current content just can't be rationalized. In fact, I would have canceled my preorder, but the option to do so was removed for whatever reason by either Steam or Turtle Rock in my purchase history prior to release. Turtlerock is now as blacklisted for me as EA, never again.

Since I couldn't save myself the money I wasted on their inordinate greed, I hope that I can save you. I also hope that if you do buy it and feel as I do that you similarly contribute a negative review. And lastly I finally hope that the large numbers of negative reviews can teach the developer that it's the quality of the user experience that will make them money, not releasing half of a half-decent game to sell us rest at $5-10 piecemeal.

reviewText:
This game is still very buggy in its current state after the Day 1 Patch. As a hunter, you will get stuck in neutral creeps and anywhere on the map if you are affected by the monster's abilities (pushed into a wall etc.).
Most of the time when you are incapacitated within a certain environment (water, cave ceiling), you will get stuck, sometimes even not able to shoot with your weapon and certainly useless for your team, because you are not reachable to get resurrected.

The mouse cursor is suddenly visible when you activate the map in the game, but will not disappear if you close the map, meaning you have to deal a mouse cursor whirling around your HUD when playing. Additionally, when in menu, the cursor randomly disappears, forcing you to restart the game.

Also, there are like 3 DLCs for every class / monster already in this game, containing of skins and a DLC pack. Why?
This is getting out of hand. Turtle Rock / 2k following the major Publishers with this kind of micropayments in a game, for which I paid full price to play, is not acceptable.

What the hell happened Turtle Rock? You had so much potential with this game!!! You just threw it away!!!
Let me just say, I am a fan of this game... Or I was... It was so unique to me, and it had this charm that most games now a days don't. It's assymetrical 4v1 style was perfect. I enjoyed every minute of it, even on the losing side, it was fun.

The game is divided into two perspectives, a first person view of the four hunters hunting a third person monster. The four hunters must use teamwork to defeat the monster, and the monster must use his skills and wit to destroy the hunters. The hunters have four classes, Assault: Damges the monster, Support: Buffs the hunters, Medic: Heals the hunters, Trapper: Traps the monster. Joke of the Year 2015.

reviewText: Gameplay:\nIt doesn't feel like a hunting game but a deathmatch arena game. Or more precise: Running behind the monster to get some average fight. Footsteps are glowing and swarms of birds are marked in the hud. And thats still not enough easy so Daisy (some dog like NPC creature of your team) is chasing the monster for you automatically as well. Unfortunately that seems necessary because the fighters or let's call them hunters" are really slow. You run
date:
empty your jetpack and run and run until you see the monster. At this time the trapper is dropping some arena shield so the monster could not run away forever and it's getting into some chaotic shooting and flying/running phase.

Teamplay:
Yes the medic have to heal but the requirement of teamplay still feels weak compared to the strong requirement in teamplay to L4D.

Graphics / world / atmosphere:
Graphic is ok. It looks better than some exclusive PC titles and runs still smoother - but compared to Crysis 1 (which was created years ago) it does not really impress me. Maybe because the world gets into background soon. The world (as well the NPCs) feels pretty insignificant. You could take the beautiful painted arena like world and replace it with a tetris block like world and it would not matter that much gameplay wise because you run and run and run and try to follow the flashy stuff and init the (most time empty) jetpack again and again anyway.

4 vs 1 (and yet another one):
Balancing feels ok but monsters feels pretty much the same... flying and shooting something or running and throwing rocks on your head surprisingly does not differ that much: It's huge
recommended:
stronger than one fighter but more important it's fast (away).

Conclusion:
I would not say it's a completely bad game and since I've paid lots of money for it I think I would continue playing from time to time. But I hoped to get a real hunting game. And I caught myself that I already started another game until few hours of testing. We already have lots of "arena shooting" games that are way cheaper (and you get your fight without running somebody behind without fuel). This is somewhat more asynchrone (4 vs 1) than traditional arena shooters but it still does not feel like something completely new to me.

If you could purchase it sometimes in sale for 10€ (including all DLCs) and if you like some arena shooter then get it."

reviewText:
Lots of game breaking bugs.
- Mouse cursor appears on screen when in FPS mode.
- Occasionally falling through the map.
- Mouse cursor disappears completely  making it very hard to navigate menus.
- Occasionally getting booted out of games with no real error or reason.
- Steamworks, if steam is down your match ends and you cannot play online.

Very poor AI breaks some map types.
- Survivor map mode AI will just wander around instead of moving towards hunters.
- Unfinished AI cases, custom game mod options will break how AI functions on some maps.
- Zero control over allied AI behavior. The monster is supposed to be able to control how its minion behaves but it is so buggy it may as well have no control.

No balance across the different class types and monsters.
- The wraith breaks almost all game mechanics with its clone and cloak ability and its dashes are so fast it cannot be trapped if it is paying attention.
- Some classes lack useful abilities for the team and are too easy for the monster to counter play against.

Poor game design.
- Massive learning curve.  The in game tutorials are very incomplete.
- Massive amount of hidden stats and mechanics, for example if you shoot a monster within 70 meters it has a massive boost to its dash regeneration.  This is stated nowhere.
- Very poor match queue system, favors throwing into games without monsters and then has one join live rather than just waiting.  Very frustrating.

You would think there would be a large amount of replay ability to something like this but it mostly feels like the same thing over and over again irrelevant of all the interesting maps.

Unsinkable intro cinematics in a buggy game prone to crashing is a huge annoyance.
The fact the developers think the currant Wraith is balanced makes me question any design future design choices they may make.

All in all I would take a 40% refund to remove this game from my steam library and instead play finished games.
One out of five as of 2-15-2015.

reviewText:
A very simple review; If you're considering purchasing Evolve, wait.

In its current state neither I nor anyone I play with from various communities can avoid crashes, disconnects and innumerable movement and interface glitches which were, oddly, not present during the game's Alpha or Beta testing phases, which I played heavily.

I've never seen the game so broken as this, and I'm unable to enjoy a single round without extremely frustrating in-game bugs, or a major crash-to-desktop. Either one or the other has marred the last ten rounds I've tried to play, with several different parties.

It may also not be a game to buy at full RRP, as I did, as the special editions and pre-order bonuses still haven't been activated on my account despite me paying a gross amount of money for this item, and investing in upgrades to my computer chiefly to facilitate playing it. The game itself is a very neat idea, and barring bugs, it can, and used to, be very entertaining. It is however, like Titanfall, very small. A small quantity of high-quality content is limited in how many hours of play it can attract from a player who isn't interested in competing professionally.

reviewText:
I like Evolve, but I don't think its worth the price; I think it has leveling and balance issues.  Also, buying the Season Pass does not get you all the DLC, only some of it.

First, Leveling in the game is required if you want to gain access to the more useful hunters or more potent monsters.  If you jump into this game late, and you play with people who have been playing for a while, expect to get your butt handed to you perpetually until you level up (which might take a long while because your XP is dependent on whether you win).  Playing the monster as a new-comer against people who have played for a while is a brutal course in futility: the hunters will find you and kill you quickly and relentlessly, and there is nothing you can do about it.  If you play a hunter as a n00b, you'll generally be riding the coat-tails of your more experienced companions, unless the more experienced monster finds you, in which case you'll just be killed in short order (and possibly eaten).  I think the game would be better if, like so may other games out there that require leveling, you could create a private game that was completely unlocked for everyone and pick the hunters/monsters you wanted, but sadly that is not an option in this game.

And then there are Balancing issues; if you join a group of players that have 6 or more levels on you, be prepared to be at a significant disadvantage.  It seems that everything you do is at a noticeable degradation compared to the other more experienced players: you seem to run slower, have less jet pack energy, weapons do less damage, healing takes longer, etc.  Because you'll die a lot, you can spend time spectating the bots and see what your abilities will be like once you do level, but when you take that bot over your abilities will degrade and you'll be forced into fighting an uphill battle to get little scraps of XP so you can level.  The leveling also seems to take forever when you try to level with groups that have a lot of experience on you because they will pick the best of their class (whether that is a hunter or monster) and you'll be stuck with the starter class.  I think the game would be better if the various playable classes (both monsters and hunters) were more equally balanced; because there's a huge disparity between the various classes gainable by leveling, as a new player, you end up on the receiving end of an exponentially longer and harder row to hoe to get to where those that have gone before you are.  My advice if your new: only play as a hunter in groups of experienced people; only play solo as the monster until you get the wraith monster; otherwise, only play solo until you get leveled.

Until some of these issues are fixed, or the price goes down, save your cash.

reviewText:
The game is fairly fun and I enjoy the asymmetric nature of the title. However it has huge issues that really hold it back from being something great which makes it hard to recommend.

One of my biggest issues with the game is the unnecessary grind to unlock hunters and monsters. You are forced to level up each skill/weapon to rank 1 before you can unlock the next hunter or monster, if something is rank 1 already it can not gain experience until every other skill/weapon is rank 1. You will feel forced playing certain characters and focusing on using a weapon or ability you don't like or that doesn't suit the situation. It took me 14 hours to unlock all the hunters and monsters.

Next is the issue where you don't get to play what you want and most often then not you'll be forced to play a hunter or a monster you don't like, over and over and over again. The game makes you preference the 5 roles in order, however it does very little to match you with the role you want which also makes the grind more annoying. People get pigeon holed into playing monster and usually leave the lobby. The game will also place you in matches that have already begone, this sucks because you don't get to play the character you want that match and if you're monster then you're probably losing.

The game doesn't offer very much variation and their isn't any interesting single player campaign. The game has bots but they aren't entertaining enough and all they do is follow you around. This is a purely multiplayer title where all the game modes feel a little to similar.

Lastly the greedy DLC model they decided to use for this title really sucks and only makes you feel like you got the cheap" version of the game because you didn't shell out the extra money for the fancy edition. There is nothing worse then paying full price and feeling like you got the cheap version.

I don't recommend this game now at full price and I don't recommend this game in the future when its on sale! By then the multiplayer scene will be on its last legs
date: its already hard enough to find matches. I don't think the games crazy DLC plans will breathe new life into this title 6 to 12 months down the line because extra characters and maps wont fix the annoying grind
recommended: repetitive gameplay and down right silly match making."

reviewText:
Initially I was very interested in Evolve. Asymmetric gameplay is a big undiscovered world with much potential and as a former dedicated L4D2 player I was hyped for this game.

Unfortunately this excitement vanished with the beta. To me the game feels empty and pointless. Arbitrary character progression is in place to give you a reason to play but the upgrades and perks you achieve do not make much of a difference. As some content is only unlocked by said progression, the system acts as a feature block, forcing you into a grind.
That would be okayish - L4D has no progression at all - the problem is, that most battles are very linear, one sided and just not as deep as one would wish, making the grind a chore.
I do not see Evolve being fun for a long time.. it's an okay game for in between.

That said I am very surprised by the insane price model the publisher is pushing here. Evolve really has not enough to offer, to justify a price point of $60 - let alone a package of DLC ramping the whole thing up to $120. This approach is not only priced without any regard to the market or the quality of your product, it's also confusing for anyone who just wants to enjoy a game.

Edit:
http://steamcommunity.com/app/273350/discussions/0/611698195154157706/
Some people just realised that the so called Hunting Season Pass actually is not a season pass. It is a single DLC package called the Hunting Season" Pass. This is not even cheeky anymore

reviewText:
Evolve is fun.  Not ALOT of fun.  But fun nevertheless.  Playing with others as a hunter can be frustrating, but also very immersive.  Playing as the monster can be quite frantic, but also quite basic.
The largest problem with this game is the repetitive nature of the gameplay.  It simply is not fun to play for any really extended length of time (as you can see the community DID NOT last).  I play a match of evolve with bots before I play other games - Or when I am done playing other games.
I dont feel inclined to write a lengthy review for this game beacuse ultimately it disappointed me all around.  I found it to be a initially fun game, but nowhere near worth the price I paid for it....

Verdict: 6.5/10
