reviewText:
WHAT HAPPENS WHEN GREAT CONCEPT TURNS TO UTTER BITTER TRASH IN REALITY.

I honestly thought this would be my new Left 4 Dead/Coop type of a game. I was mistaken.

If you have a group/team/friends that like to play together everyday. Go for it.
If you think that this game will be supported, getting better and be more fun in time. Again, you are mistaken.

As it is with any new game you buy it´s overwhelming and fun in the beginning BUT this game get´s boring pretty damn fast. DLCs are not worth a damn, neither the retail price. Awful loading times and lack of players make the game experience tedious.

The overhaul replay value goes out the window the minute you get to the max level in this game (Which is 40 and you can get it in 4 to 5 days np) and when you unlock all characters, not even going to mention A.I in this game which is a pure broken mess when you play alone with bots. Gameplay wise the game delivers and it is asymmetrical throughout the experience becoming the only great factor about this title. Difficulty does not matter in multiplayer and firepower variate between characters you select, most of the times the game will make that choice for you when you join a Lobby or a Match. (Which turns to be annoying as hell since you can not focus on evolving just one specific class you are good or interested at)

Important factors.
For hunters? Team work is important. Thus the friends or team you need play with as well as having good communication throughout a game session.
For monster? Perks.

THAT`S IT! That´s the only thing that takes to win each match. So be free to play this game and get bored after few hours. Damn, what a dissapointment.

I wish i had spet my money on something more... like GTA V.

reviewText: I really wanted to like this game. The concept was good; however, from the Big Alpha I could see there were going to be big problems with the balance of the game.  Anyone playing as the monster going against 4 humans will lose; people were already cheating, which has been corrected, I believe with the addition of some patches/updates.   The leveling system is disappointing, the game itself is extremely repetitive, the maps are really, really small.  Losing isn't fun (monster), and winning isn't fun when it happens all the time (all human hunters).   The DLC, as everyone already portrays, is really out of this world.  We paid a ton of money for this game; more than any other selling game, and now we need to pay it all over again for a little variety.  That's insane.   I thought it might be a descent replacement for LFD/LFD2; but in no way is this game anymore entertaining.  It's more frustrating than anything, which has already steered me away from it.  My last 20 attempts to play was left with bots because no on is playing this game any longer.  you took a really cool concept, some great designs, and trashed it.  I'm sorry guys.  I gave it a try, more than once.

reviewText:
Alright, this is a new version of my review towards this game, I wasn't particularly satisfied with my last one so I'll do a new one and I'll be giving my honest opinions towards this game (my opinions, might not be the actual fact about the game.)

Positive facts :

1. Evolve is a game that has awesome graphics, you could literally see the terror of monsters, the movements are so smooth that you normally don't see from any other games, the monster's captured animations are also beautiful, it's been made out like although they were captured by the wires of the trapper, you can feel their desperation or calmness (depends on how the player acts with the monster) in the captured monster, whether it goes wild or remains calm and collected, trying to find a way out.
2. Unlike other games where you are a team of four, where you have to hunt a npc boss that's programmed for obvious combos and settings, this is a game where you face an OP monster player with 4 hunter players, not to mention team work for the 4 is needed, it is also absolutely important to stay aware of everything around you, the monster has the element of surprise if it knows how to use it to his advantage, it has better detection and higher mobility (depends which monster), the monster has to beware of scaring away birds and avoid strong jungle monsters in it's early stage or health and armor would be wasted on spots where you should be keeping yourself safe until you're ready.
3. All of the monsters and hunters have their specialities, there's 4 members of hunters and 4 different roles, assault, support, trapper and medic, not to mention each of the hunter characters are different, they have different game performances and so do the monsters, with their different specialities, you have to beware of the map whether it's to your favour or it's to the monsters, different landscapes might effect the entire game play since some monsters rely heavily on surprises.
4. This is a new game published last year and updates are still coming up!

Negativities :
1. The game itself was too expensive and the DLC's too, it would be fairly nice to buy the game when it's on sale, but the DLC's are too expensive to buy for entertainment only.
2. There's barely anymore players on the game, the servers are isolated since the game is too expensive, you might have to wait for a long time until you get a multiplayer match.

Overall, it's now a pretty weird game, although the game play and designs were awesome, it's not popular due to it being overpriced and still hoping that players would pay more for the extra DLC's that should've been included in the game for free >.<
Take your own risk on buying this game, it's only worth it if you buy it during sales and for fun, I'm already regretting it a bit though ;-;

reviewText:
Left 4 Dead, Avatar and Titanfall had a lovechild. Evolve is that lovechild. The game uses first person shooting as you hunt down an alien monster with your teammates or third person hacking and slashing as the alien itself. It is a cool concept, but that's where it ends.

It's too bad this feels more like a big budget early access title than it does a finished, triple A game. There is fun to be had here, but it is very limited and you will be spending a lot of time grinding to get the items and unlocks you want. Also, each match follows a similar pattern where you just run around following an NPC which leads you to the monster before it flees, then you repeat this over and over, fighting the monster occasionally until the match ends. Maps are huge and this can often go on for 30 or 40 minutes.

There are a few balancing issues which should be ironed out with updates and the performance is actually pretty good for a PC game. But I'm just not sure it's worth the price they're asking considering how limited the base game is.

Full video review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c_MZW1Udu88

reviewText:
Thought it would be like Left 4 Dead in terms of quality.

Playing as the Monster is painful because you get tracked and bullied all game's long,
but when you get to lvl 3 you can crush the Hunters or destroy the power relay to win.
Playing the Hunters is fun if you're lucky enough to find a team that actually plays as a team.

You have no time to really set a trap or ambush because the monster moves really fast and has the ability to smell you from a distance, that makes the gameplay really fast-paced and you spend most of your time running after the monster to prevent it from feeding, EVERY GAME.

It gets boring fast and I do not think it is worth 50 euros at all because of the lack of content, repetitive gameplay and a dull story.

It's a shame because the game has a lot of potential : the world and characters are well designed, the gameplay is smooth and the animations are quite good.

Worth 20-30 euros at maximum in my opinion and should have a lot more contents.

reviewText:
LETS GET ONE THING OUT OF THE WAY: I do not give a flying ♥♥♥♥ about DLC - I haven't bought any and I'm still having loads of fun.


DESCRIPTION:
Two teams, 4 v 1. The 4 are the Hunters, they work together to track, trap and kill the 1. The 1 is a big ♥♥♥ super-monster that can kill an unprepared team of Hunters effortlessly.

Gameplay for the Hunters is like a cross between Left 4 Dead, Monster Hunter (google it) and Borderlands (each class has unique class-abilities). You can play as a Medic, Assault, Support or Trapper. Each role has a couple of unlockable Hunters with varying abilities, strengths and weaknesses. Everyone has jetpacks, but there is a bit of a learning curve in using them efficiently (which is a good thing). As long as one Hunter lives, the rest can respawn and dropship in again (this is on a fairly long cooldown, if you die after the dropship has launched, enjoy your wait).

Playing the Monster is also like Left 4 Dead, except that you are alone as the 'special infected' while being much much stronger. You can get around the map much faster than the Hunters, and generally mess with their heads/annihilate them if you have the right mindset and cunning.
The typical Monster game consists of things like ♥♥♥♥♥hit♥♥♥♥♥hitshitnomnonomnomOW♥♥♥♥♥hit♥♥♥♥♥hitnomnomRAAAGH! I win? weee
Currently you can pick from the firebreathing Tank/Fighter, the Teleporting/stealth Rogue, or the ranged/lightning flying tentacle-face dude.


MY THOUGHTS:
I played the various Alpha and Beta releases and initially found the game to be too similar to Left 4 Dead (far too simple); but after playing the full release for a few days, and the Evacuation mode (multiplayer campaign), I've come to realise that the game is ridiculously well-balanced and really deep - personal experience as a player is a lot more valuable than progression experience (just like Monster Hunter), the maps are big and open enough that you can't predict exactly how the match is going to play out. There's real 'meat' to this game.

Whoever you end up playing, it's easy to pick up the basics, but difficult to master them. The tactics you employ for each match vary wildly depending on your class(es), the environment, and the Hunt type. The maps are awesomely varied (heh, acid maps), and the wildlife is a lot of fun to deal with (fun). The autobalancing is probably the best I've ever seen, even if people drop out, lose a few games in a row, etc, the game stays fun for all involved. Matchmaking is solid, and usually lets you play your favourite role (if you insist on having one) without any trouble.

I'm always impressed by how much work the devs must have put into building up the game world, giving it a unique character all it's own. The Hunter dialogues are pretty good to listen to, especially once you get a good mix of the rarer Hunters together in the dropship.


SUMMARY:
Basically this is shaping up to be one of the best Coop games I've played since Left 4 Dead. All I need now is a regular crew and some Teamspeak tactics :)








STILL WORRYING OVER DLC?The (overpriced) skins are optional, and the addtional Hunters and Monsters are not available yet (if the devs pay the same attention to balancing as they have done with the rest of the player characters, the DLC PCs won't confer any particular advantage either).
It's easy to underestimate the effort and production values the devs have put into game balancing (it's amazing)  and cutscenes/interactions. I suspect the Season Pass (overpriced) will make more sense as players mature with unlocks and progression - new Hunters and Monsters will affect both game balance and the various cutscenes and player character dialogues, probably a lot of work involved in that.

reviewText:

Whoever is making the decisions of what goes in the game and what doesn't, I'm sorry but you're just purely stupid, and need to start rethinking things.

Pros:

-Devs seem care a lot about the game, except the monetization (see below)

Cons:
-DLC is ludicrously overpriced (really REALLY should have had a $30 flat 'real' season pass that actualy came with all the future characters)
-The above has lead to a rapid drop in player count
-Promised Free Map DLCs are on a crazy slow drip compared to paid character DLC


I had a lot of fun with this game, but I can't recommend paying more than maybe $15-$20 if they keep the DLC system the way it is. I'd be willing to pay much more if they would release a 'real' season pass with ALL DLC instead of these bullsh*t 'Hunting Season Pass' things.

Game: 8/10
Monetization: 1/10
Final Score: 6/10, tentative thumbs up

reviewText:
If you have a reliable group of friends to play the game with,  it can actually be a lot of fun.  Outside of that though, it's a crapshoot.

The single player AI is maddening in that if you're playing the Monster, the Hunters are relentless BMFs.  If you're playing as the Hunters though, it's like they're all rejects from the Keystone Cops and if you're taking that monster down, it's basically all up to you.  The Monster AI is also aggravatingly canny at determining which hunter YOU are playing, and pounding on you EXCLUSIVELY until there's nothing left but a red jelly smashed into the dirt.

You can mitigate the AI ineptitude somewhat by customizing the settings, but that kind of feels like cheating to me for some reason, and thus any victories earned that way seem hollow.

The maps I've played so far have been interesting to play on, though as the monster I wish there were more places to hide/lurk for an ambush.

I also wish there was a way to move into a 1st-person view as the monster because all-too-often in tighter terrain the camera goes completely wonky and you can't see anything but your own backside, making it impossible to target the hunters with attacks.  I know the 3rd person view gives a better sense of scale to the monster, but when I'm getting shot up and the camera blinds me, it's frustrating to the point of just wanting to quit the game.

So overall I'm giving this game a No" vote
date: but with the proviso that if you play with friends (not just random people who won't coordinate)
recommended: it can actually be a good time."

reviewText:
A very cool concept, ruined by lack of players.
After logging almost 100 hours of time into this game, it pains me to say that this game is done.

Simplified Review: It's not worth buying when there's nobody to play with.  Rest In Peace Evolve 2015-2015

Back when it came out, and a few months following, it was an amazing gaming experience. An awesome blend of cooperative tactical action, and a lone wolf position all blended into one. It was Monster hunter in the future where you could be the monster. Awesome

Recently, I fired up the game again to relive some good memories and have some fun. but after a stifling 20 minute wait for a monster to be found, i realized that this game isnt populated anymore. The implimented Ranking system" that works the matchmaking requires some absurd amount of games played to even place you. It's only absurd because you can't get games to play. Within the recent couple times i played i got 2 games in. one the day this was written
date: and one the day before.\n\nI miss it's hayday... I really do. Now the community is gone. An amazing title left to die alone."

reviewText:
Markov scanned the jungle floor, searching for monster tracks hidden under the darkness of the verdant jungle canopy.

The other hunters lied dead behind him - friends, now reduced to piles of meat by the ravaging beast they had come to kill.  It had torn through his suit and his stomach, but one hand was enough to hold his gun as he used the other to stop his innards from spilling out onto the ground.  They had weakened it, but it fled from him, and he just needed to find it and put it down to avenge his friends.

It was only when he heard the growls behind him that he realized he didn't have to find the beast.  It had already found him.

Markov screamed, Goliath!  I will hang your head on my wall!" and pulled the trigger on his assault rifle.

As the bullets plinked harmlessly against the bleeding beast's thick skin Markov realized with horror that he hadn't paid the extra $20 for the "Damage-dealing-ammunition" DLC.

The monster swung its powerful arm
recommended: into Markov and sent him flying through the air
hoursPlayed: where he glitched out and started breakdancing for no particular reason as his mouse cursor suddenly appeared on his screen.  Markov watched helplessly as the monster swaggered over
voteText: holding bags of money in each claw
helpfulPercent:
and crushed him to death under its preorder bonuses.

Storytime over.

3/10
Pros:
+Decent game
+Fun gameplay while it lasts
+Feels like hunting a monster through a jungle.

Cons:
- Literally one game mode with custom game modes so indistinguishable from the basic mode that it would take modders two weeks to create them in their free time
votesHelpful:
like if Halo had been sold for $60 with no campaign or non Deathmatch game options.
- I have played $20 games with more content and passion put into them than this $60 game.
- You would be better off spending $3 on an Orion: Prelude 4-pack to play with friends.
- No
votesTotal: really.  Evolve offers less content than a game that costs literally exactly the same amount of money as a can of coke.\n- Game is built as a DLC cash grab
votesFunny: much like the "Sims" games - except that the Sims at least wait for a bit before releasing their shameless DLC
commentsCount:
including features that should have been included in a full price retail game anyway.

Bottom line?

I'll still be playing games like Left 4 Dead and Orion: Prelude next year.
My friends will be lucky if they can convince me to play another repetitive round or two of Evolve as I mourn $60 that would have been better spent on cheaper games with more to offer."

reviewText:
ALPHA TESTING REVIEW:

Thoughts after a few games:

Extremely entertaining game (at least thus far)
Easy learning curve for beginners, I feel, but a long one to become really good at the game
Very nice looking game, but was quite demanding on my system (to max out, anyways) and actually froze at the start of the first match; turned down to medium for my second

Pros:
- Gorgeous environments
- Plenty of flora and fauna
- Guns feel somewhat authentic; each one feels well designed and powerful (and unique)
- 4-man squads work perfectly (however, when one person disconnects it suddenly becomes VERY 1-sided)
- Regardless of what people are saying, this game is FUN, and I definately think it's worth a try

Cons:
- SUPER RELIANT ON JETPACKS TO MOVE ACROSS MAPS (I feel like some of the structures should have ladders that you can use when you are either trying to save jetpack or trying to be stealthy, or if you're simply out of jetpack and running for your life)
- Against a really good monster, 90% of the match is you following his (or her) tracks, then meeting a highly evolved monster that wrecks you in the first actual meeting
- Exp grind. At a certain point, this game turns from fun, into an XP grind afair (which I am not a fan of)
- PRICE TAG. $70 CAD FOR THIS GAME? That is so unjustified. Just because a game looks good, doesn't mean it's worth a $70 price-tag. This game does not have enough maps, different guns, or different playstyle for it be justified at $70, in my opinion

Thoughts
I would buy this game on sale, but at a pre-release price of $70 I know that I won't be playing this game anytime soon; (even a 50% off sale still puts this game @ $35, which imo, is still high. I'd value this game at $45, and would likely get it on sale if a few things were added/fixed)

Suggestions:

- increase the number of playstyles for hunters. At the moment, all you really do is hunt, shoot, retreat/push. You can't really set up an ambush, or have one player take the high ground with a sniper rifle and harass the monster while calling out positions for your companions (but make it so that the sniper would be SUPER vulnerable if he didn't move/hide)

- explosive barrels/stuff; having an environment that you can use against the monster, I feel, would help a lot of the Hunters (as a good monster makes himself (or herself) scarce for much of the early part of the game)

- pick-up-able items; make some of the explosive barrels pick-up-able so that hunters can carry them and set up traps and ambushes, or block off a certain area to the Monster (without it taking serious damage). Even adding things like an insta medpac, or 2x jetpack fuel. (I would also suggest allowing the monster to throw certain things back, increasing the amount of ways to play, and changing situations)

- ranking (not sure if this is a thing, but i'd like it to be. 4 of us 1st game guys went up against a 4th level monster in our second game, and he destroyed us. half of the game he hid, then when he was strong enough, he just charged us and destroyed us. Wasn't a very fun experience)

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Second edit, more pondering

AMMUNITION; the lack of there being ANY ammunition SEVERLY OVERPOWERS THE HUNTERS EARLY. I understand that it' sort of necessary for the FINAL fight, but for the whole game having to NEVER re-supply is a bit silly. It would add another meta level to the game: ammo awareness. So you can just spam shots willy nilly hoping to hit the monster and do a little damage to it. Additionally, if you instantly find the monster, and run out of ammo, it gives the monster a chance to escape and hopefully evolve a little bit, or even heal if anything. But having the Hunters literally have no consequences for just spamming their weapons seems a little unbalanced to me. If the Relay had like, crates of ammo that you needed to return to to restock, or call in a dropship to drop of a crate on the fly, I think THAT would add a whole nother dimension to the game.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------



----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

OVERALL RECOMMENDATION: This game is extremely good, satisfying and tense, but I feel that it is NOT justified by it's price-tag. I would pick this game up for anything under $35. There is no single player for you to practice on, learn maps, creatures, playstyles, etc, and I feel that that limits the game somewhat. I think a simple TEST MAP" or practice arena would help many people
date: ESPECIALLY FIRST TIME MONSTERS. I look forward to picking this game up upon a sale

reviewText:
So finally ready to write a review of Evolve.

Evolve is by far one of the most fun online FPS games I´ve played for a long long time.

Important Note - Evolve is not a game for everyone at all, it is a game that you have to spend a lot of time on learning as monster or have a really great group if you are hunters

So to break it down.

Graphic wise Evolve is top of the line, nothing to complain about at all, I´m running everything maxed and my GPU has no issues running it, however make sure your GPU doesn´t overheat when running this game at those settings as it is a demanding game but it is sooo worth it in every aspect.

Gameplay wise Evolve is pretty simple and very easy to understand, you are either hunters or a monster, the hunters job is to kill the monster and the monters job is to survive, evolve and kill the hunters, pretty stright forward really.  However there is different gamemodes atm there is Hunt and Evacuation both brings different challanges and unique things into the game.

As you play you unlock new hunters or monster types and perks that will help you with either survival or killing whatever you prefer. Personally I´ve fallen in love with beeing a monster sneaking around and picking people off one by one soooo much fun hearing them rage in the map change screens ^_^

Community this game is top of the line too, there is build in voice chat, however unlike a LOT of other games, people here seems to in fact only talk and use it for game related things, even the games I´ve played with completely random people they have been good at team play, nice, polite well minus one guy who I`m sure was fapping ><

All in all this game is great and one of those games I will keep returning to for sure as more content gets added with DLC´s and we know it will as it is published by 2K who is masters of DLC´s (Check borderlands 2) but honestly I cannot wait.

If the price is scaring you a bit then wait for a sale, but if you like online FPS team play do NOT miss out on this title!

reviewText:
Being a big L4D2 fanboy, I waited a long time for this game. I expected it to be the next evolution of coop and VS. The game is beautiful. A few matches and I thought is was basically perfect. Then after some time with the game, I found the following.
1) The game has no legs. You get sick of the repetition very quickly. Some say it lacks content. I think more maps or charterers and you still have a boring game.
2) The marketing and sale of addons was a classroom example of how to anger a player base. They charge for everything and even the definition of Season Pass was changed. There were multiple season passes (basically one for Hunters, and one for Monsters). To make matters worse, you don't get everything you expect. Then to make matters even worse, they started adding Season Pass 2's. Unbelievable.
In the end, I think they created the game they wanted to create. It just isn't that much fun. Add to that the botched marketing of the addons, and you have a perfect formula for disappointment. I still pick it up occasionally but I would not recommend this game.

reviewText:
This is a game clearly designed for multiplayer. There's little if any competitive scene as far as I'm aware, so it's pubs all the way. If you have a good mic, are comfortable communication intentions/tactics with a team, and you can work past the fact that alone, you're nothing more than a quick meal to the beasts you'll encounter, you'll love hunting giant monsters as the hunters of Shear! If you're new, have no fear - there are short (skippable) video tutorials on the basics and advanced tactics of all the monsters and hunters should you feel overwhelmed.

If you're more of a solo player, who dreams of getting the chance to outplay and outwit a group of four other players as you don the role of the boss battle of the map, you'll love being a deadly monster, though be careful - the game is balance such that the level of your evolution dramatically effects your odds against intelligent players.

Stage 1 - The odds are against the monster.
Stage 2 - The odds between you and the hunters are even.
Stage 3 - The odds are stacked against the hunters.

Stealth, good movement, situational awareness, a good understanding of the game mechanics, and patience will be necessary to succeed as the highly adept apex predators of Shear.

You can group up with friends, or play with strangers. You CAN play solo against bots, though beyond familiarizing yourself with mechanics/characters/monsters and maybe grinding out achievements, the AI quickly becomes repetitive and the thrill is lost quickly without the element of human creativity.

I DO NOT recommend this game if you're looking for a fun game to play alone, for storyline, if you don't like to talk while you game, or if you're easily frustrated by failure. No doubt, you will fail a great deal as you're coming to terms with how to play the game. I also do not recommend this game if you are looking for non-stop action, as a great deal of the game revolves around the hunt" of the monster. It's quite possible in some matches that you'll spend ten minutes before you even find the monster. On that note

reviewText:
I just want to give my 2 cents about evolve. It seems all the top reviews are negative and may not accuretly reflect how good this game is. I returned from a year overseas in June and I was excited to play this game. As soon as i got on steam I saw it had mixed reviewes and all the top reviews aere negative. After reading them I decided to pass on the game.

Well 3 months later the game went on sale and I bought the Monster hunter pack and all the dlc for something like $40. I have not been disapointed. There has been a major update since most of the reviews so anything prior to Hunt 2.0 is nearly irrevelent. Just like any MP game out there, your experience may vary based on your team or the team your playing against. This is a game that is easy to get into but takes some time to really become good at it. Unfortunetly many people treat the classes as if they are playing COD and when they pick and how they play it only effects them. By that I mean if you pick support, your job is to buff teamates or debuff the monster. Its also your main goal on a team wipe to be the last person alive to allow your team to respawn in. You are not the assault and damage to the monster is not your main priority. This is the main problem with randoms in MP.... every class wants to be DPS when it is simply not there job. Once you play with players who realize this, the game become amazing, challenging, and just a blast to play.

I would highly recomend finding at least one other person to play with but if you cant, remember that the MIC is your friend. The game has built in voice chat that works flawlessly and youd be suprised how many game i was certain id loose only to turn it around with the use of communication.

I urge you that if this is a game youve been considering, go for it. It may have its frustrations (mainly as a hunter with randoms) but it also has some of the most fun gameplay ive played in a while. I would also recomend going to the official forums (https://talk.turtlerockstudios.com/) if you want more information about the game. Dont let all these negative reviews keep you from a great game.

reviewText:
-Through an array of intelligent design choices, developer Turtle Rock Studios has created a smart, asymmetric, multiplayer monster-hunting game that plays unlike anything else. It’s tactically deep, bursting with character, and once you get past its mildly obtrusive progression system, it offers a level of nuance rarely found in multiplayer shooters.Turtle Rock extends that “easy to learn, hard to master” virtue across most of the experience and Evolve benefits immensely from it.

-The monster needs to move quickly and carefully, balancing the need to put distance between itself and the hunters with the need to find food to level up. It’s ahigh-stakes tightrope act that requires good map knowledge, and a strong grasp of the monster’s surprising number of non-combat abilities like climbing, sneaking, and sniffing around. For as effectively as they exude an intimidating physical presence, playing the monster successfully requires patience and skill. Overpowering the hunters is really just your reward for outsmarting them, which makes ripping them to shreds as a max-level monster feel just as satisfying as it looks and sounds.

-As the hunters, the continually interesting challenge is to find a cunning monster that doesn’t want to be found amidst the sprawling and beautifully realized planet of Shear. Fresh tracks and startled birds are among the more obvious clues, but following them like a bread crumb trail is rarely enough. You need to reason out where the monster is headed, and make effective use of your team’s amusing sci-fi gadgets. You might tag tempting wildlife with a tracking dart, so that when the monster eats it you can get a bead on its location, or pursue a monster with an unmanned drone to relay his position to your teammates. Since every second that passes without the monster in your crosshairs is another step closer to it becoming nigh-unstoppable, hunts are every bit as thrilling as they are nuanced. Though it’s hard to take it all in when you’re embroiled in an intense monster fight, Evolve looks and sounds remarkably good. The ground rumbles deeply with Goliath’s every step,  Kraken’s Lightning Strikes light up the screen, Wraith's extraordinary agility, and Behemoth the tank of a monster" who can morph into a massive
date: sending Hunters tumbling in every which direction while startled wildlife scatter in fear.\n\n-Each individual element is well executed
recommended: but combined as whole during a match’s most pitched moments
hoursPlayed: the complete picture really is a sight to behold.\nThe true beauty of Evolve

reviewText:
My review of Evolve (mainly hunter play time. I'm a bad monster player) after more than 12 months of playing...

Well, i obviously love this game. not for any other reason than: IT'S GREAT!

People new to this game should be aware of a few points though:

1]
It's a sharp learning curve when you first start. Join quick play and everyone will be yelling at you to do this or do that. It really can be rough but hang on in there. Find a character class that you enjoy playing and stick to it for a while.
2]
As you get better at playing and win a few games you will start to understand the characters and how they work together OR NOT!
3]
You gain a few hundred hours play time and think you're a boss but get stuck beating higher level opponents. At this stage do some research: for example. it took me months to learn the sound of the 'spotter'. It's call tells you in which direction the monster is. Google it.
4]
By this stage you will have found a group a friends who you will regularly play with. This part is tricky. Some you will want to go 'ranked hunting' with (usually because they are better than you) and some who you don't want to go 'ranked hunting' with (usually because they are not as good as you and will drop your rank... a lot).
5]
My best tip is to watch some streamers to see what they do. Watch youtube videos on 'feeding routes' if you play monster or hunter you will need to be aware of where the food spawns on the maps.
6]
A big point at this level is dodging and keeping in 'line of sight' of your support, so that they can shield you when the monster attacks. Dodging takes time and practise. I'm still rubbish at both!
7]
Finally, work as a team. Communicate. The best way to kill a monster is to get a good early dome, IN A GOOD LOCATION. This means with no loops that the monster can run around/ get out of sight. No aggressive wildlife that will take down half the teams health and perhaps a nice big tree or small rock to run around. This will allow the assault player to do more damage.

I don't care about the DLC buy it if you want. You don't need it.

reviewText:
Firstly try to not be influenced by the bad press regarding DLC. It's the same for all games nowadays and is the fault of greedy publishers and the whole 'pay to win' cancer that's found its way from mobile phones to video games. DLC for Evolve consists of cosmetic enhancements to monsters or hunters, a new monster and t4 hunters that have just been introduced (it's not pay to win). You can still fully enjoy this game without any DLC!

This is the first FPS game since Half Life 2 that has had me hooked for over 500 hours and even now at 'high level play' it has plenty more to offer. It's the first of it's kind and a breath of fresh air in the FPS market. It's not for teen CoD fan boys who think they can just point and shoot at a monster and expect immediate glory... These players have left in their thousands as they're are incapable of working coherently as a team when the odds are so often stacked against you. In this respect there is a steep learning curve but it's with persevering with if you're more mature.

The premise of the game is as follows: 4 Hunters/players with their own distinct roles track and chase a monster (1 player) on the run, who has to feed on wildlife to evolve to a more powerful beast! At the start of each game the odds are stacked in favour of the hunters, when the monster evolves to stage 2 or 3 things become more interesting and rely heavily on good hunter team play to survive against a monster who is now capable of destroying a power relay or hunt the hunters to win.

It's hard not to be impressed by what Turtle Rock have achieved here, the detail and variety in maps based on the alien world Shear is exceptional. A great deal of effort and thought has gone into each map and the wildlife, which adds another dimension to Evolve.

Overall I feel this is one of the best games I have ever played. It has unparalleled depth and is truly unique. My only concern is once you have played with an experienced team you'll never want to play this in a pick up group.... The margin for error on the hunter side is very small and you will find yourself getting very frustrated in PUGs. I started with PUG's, but very quickly found a good core of players through steam to play with. Don't be put off, worth every penny!

10/10

reviewText:
I love this game, I really do. Or I should say I loved it, with the repeated 'balancing' from TRS its not fun to play as either the hunter OR the monster due to ridiculous over/underpoweredness. If you play as the monster you either spend hours smashing bronze randoms or getting absolutely destroyed by premade groups of hunters that know exactly how to take down the monster. Which is easy if you have either Lazarus as the healers (completely broken and overpowered with a premade group) or if you play on one of the five maps that are so completely unbalanced for the hunters to win its ridiculous. Along with TRS shoving expensive DLC down our throats they made the game pay to win on the hunter side, with each new hunter completely breaking any strategy the monster may have to win.  The game was decently balanced before the new Hunt Season updates were released, it was insanely fun as the monster to be pit up against teams of premades that made it difficult, but not improbable to win. Now due to the monster nerfs its incredibly improbable to win a game against premade hunters unless you have 100% of everything going for you (which is impossible due to the new 'balancing') Honestly if you play a game that relies on one side making mistake after mistake in order to make it winable then whats the point of playing by yourself as the Monster (which isnt fun anymore) or playing by yourself as the Hunters (which is nearly impossible to win against even the worst of Monster players). Seriously this game is only being pushed for a larger playerbase because they want more money from all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t DLC they keep shoving down our throats.

I mean, come the ♥♥♥♥ on, 5 dollars for a skin? Why not make it a ♥♥♥♥ing unlockable? The only unlockable skins are those gained from gaining elite status on a character, which is another reason the game is broken.

In a game where a Monster with elite status vs a team of Hunters with elite status, the Hunters will win almost all of the time, especially if you are playing with a premade group of try hards. This game just has almost nothing going for it except the first few hours of fun it has once you break into it. Its not worth the full price, its barely worth half price, and I shelled 100 ♥♥♥♥ing dollars for the ultimate pack and got basically nothing from it.

The new matchmaking system is terrible as well. If you play as the monster you spend half the time completely overwhelming bronze hunters and getting completley thwomped against silver hunters. There is no middle ground.

This game is supposed to be DECENTLY CHALLENGING, yet STILL FUN. Even if you don't care about winning its not even fun. Its a boring grind fest while waiting for the new season of hunters/monsters while playing against the same four hunters over and over again.

Seriously. I have played the same premade group of four hunters five times in a row. Five ♥♥♥♥ing times. And their strategy never changed because its ridiculously underpowered as the Monster at the moment, but its over powered for the Hunters if they are playing with three of their 'friends' and do the right thing everytime.

TL;DR Don't buy this unless you like playing a game with a shrinking playerbase and extreme balance issues. And love shelling out ridiculous amounts of money for needless ♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
The game itself is pretty fun for a small amount of time, but it becomes apparent the progression system really hinders the variation that could possibly come. It felt awfully grindy to play this game after the first few rounds after fighting the same old monster with the same old tactics.

Playing as the monster, while it was REALLY fun at first, became a massive snooze fest of just running in circles, criss crossing chasms, throwing them for a loop, until I ate what I required to take on the hunters, as it was impossible for them to catch up to me without splitting up, which you can then clearly exploit with extreme prejudice.

Overall, the gameplay is very gimmicky, and with games only lasting about 5-15 minutes on average. Especially, with only two game modes and the linear progression system This game gets dull rather quickly and is best played in small bursts.
And the ability for 4 friends to play as the hunter, and not have a fifth as the monster seems like it is a feature that is really needed. I felt that I would've loved to taunt my friends as a monster, especially with the gimmicks at hand, it would only be improved further by adding mind games.

As for the games Options, the poor optimization for PC really shows, with no customizable options beyond Low, Medium, High, AA , V-sync and Tessellation. And even on the lowest settings my fairly compotent rig was struggling to chug along as a hunter, despite the game not even looking that good graphically. As a monster, it was fine for some reason and after some messing around the game runs smooth on high as the monster. I'm unsure of the reason for this at this moment in time.

Overall, with the way this is looking the game is rather amusing and entertaining, but I wouldn't warrent it worthy of the price tag it will be asking for.
$20-$30 would seem more reasonable with what has currently been shown.
I seriously wish steam had a third option for Meh"
recommended: or a no.\n\nI'm going to be giving it a no on the grounds that it should hoopefully show that some improvments need to be made for this title to shine."

reviewText:
So, I finally got round to playing a fairly new release AAA game, and I went with Evolve. I was rather sceptical with purchasing it at full price on launch, however I was able to get a key fairly cheap from another site so decided it was worth a try.

I'll start off with the graphics; this is one of the best looking games I've ever seen. Played on full settings and the environments just look stunning. The lighting looks spectacular as well.

The games main aim revolves around a group of four hunters chasing after a monster. There are four different classes available, assault, trapper, support and medic. Each of these classes are well balanced and gives you all sorts of different weapons and abilities. My personal favourite is the support class.

Audio in Evolve is very important, at times you have to rely on it a lot to try and listen out for the monster when you are trying to find it. Every single sound effect is done to perfection.

There are two different game modes that I have found, regular skirmishes and Evacuations. I have been putting a lot of time in Evacuations which is essentially five different games; each having different objectives, but each game is different depending on how you have done in the rest of the maps. For instance, if the monster manages to destroy a power plant in on map, the next will have toxic gas floating around. Apparently there are around 800,000 different combinations of scenarios available through this mechanic, which can only be a good thing if you ask me.

The difficulty of Evolve can vary. My first match I was playing as the humans, and obviously the monster was a more experience player with a lot of skill as it completely wiped the floor of our team, but sometimes you can get matched up with a lesser skilled monster and it be the complete opposite.  The game entirely depends on how good the monster player is to be honest.

I have been playing for about seven hours now and I don't see myself giving up any time soon, I still feel as if I have barely scratched the surface in terms of content to see and experience. I have been playing with a friend the past few hours which has also added to the fun, I think it would be perfect if you had a full team of people you know on voice chat.

From what I have seen so far, there doesn't seem to be an underlying story, just each game offers you a little story in its own right.

I only encountered one technical issue, and it wasn't exactly game breaking, just more of an annoyance, my mouse cursor was showing on screen as well as the cross-hair of my gun, not a major issue, one that was fixed by quickly restarting the client.

Do I recommend Evolve? Sure - I am having an absolute blast playing it. The only complaints I see in reviews are from people who say it has no replay ability, but they have poured 50+ hours into it already....to me that sounds like you have had plenty of replay ability out of it. Another complaint people seem to have is that there isn't anyone playing... well at the time of writing this, there is ~1200 people playing. That's a pretty large number considering you only need 4 other people to get a game going. Evolve is certainly one of my favourite games of the year so far, and one that I will be continuing to dip into to play with friends, I'd seriously recommend this, maybe wait for the sales to start if you were sceptical like me, but it is worth it.

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

reviewText:
Evolve is team vs solo player Left 4 Dead style shooter. One players plays as the monster while the other team of 4 are tasked to bring it down. The concept is unique and fun. The weapons for each hunter are interesting and result in a variety of play styles - enough to keep interesting but simple enough to not be overwhelming. You will find three types of monsters. They fall into the main archetypes - warrior (Goliath), mage (Kraken) and rogue (Wraith).

Mechanically, this game is a console to PC port. It still plays well, there have been no issues with online play, and there are a variety of available resolutions. Just don't expect this game to justify a PC upgrade or anything.

The game currenlty suffers from severe balance issues that were not really present during the open beta. Why the devs decided to change so much in the wrong direction is an interesting question. Many of the hunters offer no advantage to the more popular picks, some of poor to the point where they will set your team at a severe disadvantage. Decent monster players are capable of killing your entire team at level 2 in one go without great difficulty, which they really shouldn't be.

This game would be great but the above issues really hold it back. Hopefully a patch or new DLC may bring this game back to the hype that it should have had.

If the game were 30.00 dollars versus 60.00 then we would have a good buy. But considering the balance issues and lack of content currently I would recommend a pass. However, it is good enough that if you have already purchased it, or have a group of friends to play with, it is still worth your time. Future patches or expansions may make this game from a average game to a great game.

reviewText: This game seems really interesting at first glance. Four hunters chasing down a lone monster in an epic fight to the death. Unfortunatly this game ultimately just turns into a very long game of tag. The monster barely hides. It is more efficient to just run from the hunters and feed little by little until you hit stage 3 and just turn on them. Hunters in the mean time simple follow along at a slow pace contantly needing to recharge their jets, due to the overwhelming number of cliffs that require traversing, slowly dying to all the wildlife they encounter along the way. Unlike the zombies from the Left 4 Dead series, which dealt overall minor damage to most players except when utilized properly by the infected, the creatures in this game seem dead set on seeing you.... well dead. Too much of the wildlife perma-traps hunters, until they get rescued by a teammate, and kill them. This mechanic, along with the monsters sneak attack on hunters, restricts players from doing anykind of real 'split and corner' strategy efficiently. If you have a full team of five people to play with this game might be a bit more fun but for $60 a person just doesn't seem to be worth it. Not to mention the fact that the season pass doesn't include any of the optional skins that they sell in the shop. Actually the season pass doesn't even mention, at the time of writing this review, what it actually includes at all.

reviewText: Most of the game play for this game takes place with a group of uncoordinated hunters chasing down a monster that does laps around the map for about 10 minuets in order to get level 3 to ensure victory. The matches seem very one sided 99% of the time.\nIf your looking to play with just one other friend this is not the game for you. I feel like the developers went for a game that was not supposed to be won by the hunters unless they were actually trying to do it right. If you want Call of Duty: Monsters, this is not it.
If you are looking for something different, that is challenging and new, Evolve may very well make your day. It has for me anyways.

reviewText:
Let me bullet point this for you.

*Long ♥♥♥ load times.
*Random crash to desktop.
*Losing party members randomly.
*Wraith has been OP since release and still remains the reigning champion.
*Gameplay is fairly shallow for the hunters.
*Massive imbalances making some characters useless on certain maps and on certain teams (example hank's airstrike doesn't work if there is no line of sight with the sky and some maps have an abundance of no sight to ground.)
*Singleplayer is tacked on ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t with extremely boring game play. Consider it a tutorial if you will, but it really isn't fun at all.
*Most game modes are boring and the primary game mode, although a cool idea, is generally too shallow to last.
*A lack of depth. Just four moves for monsters and four for hunters. It's just so shallow.
*Disgusting amounts of terrible DLC meaning you will have to pay to play some classes (unless that changed. During the free week everything seemed to be unlocked, but there is no word whether it will stay this way for all players. Indicators in the shop show that it will probably revert to normal after.)


With all that said, I'd buy it for 10 bucks, but no more than that.

reviewText:
The gameplay is awesome, of course sense it's a team based game playing with random people in matchmaking can be a drag sometimes but I wont fault the game for that because every team game has this issue. Just look at the toxic LoL game...

It's a shame they want so much money for what this is, the content that is there is fun but very limited. How many times can you rinse and repeat the same thing over and over before you get bored? I would say that new maps, game modes, hunters and monsters is something to look forward too and could definately make this game even better but we all know that those additions will cost as much as another premium AAA game itself which is dissapointing.

It's sad what is happening to games these days. They release with bugs that devs knew about, simple online modes fail, or in Evolves case, they want cash for every upgrade and not only that but they want A LOT of cash for these upgrades. Skins for a single hunter should not be $7 especially because it's only for weapons.

TLDR: I would recommend playing this but honestly I hope people wait until either the price drops, (If that ever happens with these greedy game dev's and publisher,) or just buy the standard game if this is really something you think you will enjoy without having to dish out another $100 for the cool kid stuff.

reviewText:
Evolve TL;DR:
Evolve is an asymetrical multiplayer co-op game (as the hunters) or a mad power fantasy lone wolf (as the monster) experience. It's also a $30 dollar game at best masquerading as a $60 dollar game because it's a new IP. Unless you have money to burn it's just not worth it.

The Good
A fresh new take on asymetrical combat
Well created world
The character designs really come to life with their banter
Genuinely solid shooting as the hunters with some cool individual abilities
A well matched game where everyone is of equal skill feels truly epic
The Meh
The game is drowning in a sea of DLC most of which is aesthetic but when your game is pretty much a hand full of modes with the same implimentation it could have used these useless skins as unlocks to at least make the game have more going for it towards replayability
The Ugly
Feels like a console port
Often times games are incredibly one sided and very boring (either the hunters end it in a few minutes or you don't see the monster for 15 minutes and they they destroy you)
Load times
Still very buggy
When all else fails use Wraith
The emphasis on just getting people in games as opposed to letting them choose the quality of their play time
Lack of content
The part where I ramble:
I played in both the alpha and the beta and the experience is much the same. Good close matches are incredibly rare at maybe 1 in 10 games. The rescue, nest, and defense modes add new elements but not enough to keep it fresh for long.

The developers odd choice to remove player control is one of the things that I think is the greatest sin of Evolve. Not allowing the player to choose basic things like starting at character select, the begining of a map rotation, or choosing to play a single class is just basic game design. Yes it may take them longer to get in the game but for some people it's not about the quantity of play time but the quality of it.

reviewText:
After 50+ matches, consensus; Game is fantastic, players are garbage.

The mechanics of the game are great. Proper teamwork is required to take down a stage 3 monster but it is tough. There is no excuse to be taken down by stage 1 monsters yet I do it to teams all the time.

Much like the issue with L4D the players are what's wrong with this game.

Monster mechanics and the smoothness of the game (save for some bugs here and there, disappearing creature corpses, can't eat, laggy skills) are fantastic, playing as the monster is super fun and when I played with 2 other friends playing as the hunters is great too.

Most people playing this ATM have no concept of how to play. Yes a tutorial would be handy, yet every time you play a class it gives you a tutorial movie on how every single skill works and should be used. The only learning curve I can see in the game that needs to be explained better are the random creatures in game.

But for those that don't know here ya go. As a monster, if the creature is yellow it's food and will not attack unless hit. Orange, will attack if provked E.G. get up in it's personal space. Creatures with icons above their heads give buffs when eaten, E.G. Faster movement, faster eating, shorter skill cooldowns etc. Red monsters are those actively aggressive towards you and will chase you.

As humans, icons above creature heads also gives you buffs. Most creatures will not attack you unless provoked and some will attack you as you walk by. In most cases it's a waste of time and HP to attack creatures as it leaves carcasses for the Monster to eat and evolve and you gain nothing.

That's it.

reviewText:
So this Game I'm sure everyone has at least heard about by now but if you havent. It's been a looked forward to game for awhile made by the same people that made Left 4 Dead. With somewhat the same concept in mind, in this game its 4v1 with really level playing grounds on all fronts. A game that can be competetive or just fun, you can play it with friends or by yourself with randoms all being really fun at least through my eyes.

The Pros:
-Really balanced classes on all sides. Which in a game like this it's a must need otherwise it can end up a tilted game.
-Short games, typically these games run between 10-20 minutes on average(depends on the team and the person playing the monster)making it easy access for people that can't play games for too long
-The community, the community in any game is pretty important and sense it's a game primarily run on its community for match ups its important to have a decent one. From my experience this game has a pretty decent community
-The updates often balance things that my seem a little off in classes the Devs stay close to this game they didn't just release it and leave it to build a new game. They take in account how many people play the game etc.
-Classes you play in the game take a bit of time to find the right one that suits you but once you do. It's just extremely fun to be able to play a game where you can pick it up and say Yep this is mine" to a class.

The Cons:
-Games that last over 20 minutes seem to feel too much like a drag to play past the point when a team won't co-operate
-Matching is kinda wonky getting paired up with a team at your first level and going against someone that has maxed out all his abilities
-There is much room for improvements on weapons i feel like a bit of customization to make a class truely feel unique to your playstyle needs to be incorporated

Now this isn't some game you have to enjoy a story or anything
date: so if your looking for that try something like Skyrim or an RPG because this game doesnt have it. This game is a primary multiplayer game its meant to be played with a team/friends which isnt bad just know that you are buying a multiplayer game not anything else. Nothing more nothing less."

reviewText:
Not a bad game, but not an awesome game like L4D .

I mostly played hunter, EVOLVE offers a crazy atmosphere and some good games, but I found three major flaws :

- Console setting : most weapons / tools requires no precision in aiming. A shame for a FPS.
- Lack of pace in tracking phases. The monster has all the tools to give the tempo of the game and have fun. On Hunter side we systematically walk with our asthmatic jet-pack, even when we know well the map. Rather painful. Especially, excluding some stalking skills, there is not much to do other than to press Z and space. The universe is really nice but seems unnecessary, it soon ignored.
- Fights are too oriented MOBA : bad players impact more than good players. Each character is incomplete (lack of damage / can't capture / can't heal / can't survive well), so no question of fun if you are a lonewolf or hope raise the level of a team with a solid skill like in a conventional team-based FPS. The team will always be pulled down by the worst player. This guy will regularly kills the game by failing his class action, leaving others as spectators of the downfall of the team. Really frustrating.

I pass over the horrible interface (5 min of loadings for 10 minutes of gaming) and the disgusting marketing (Day one DLC, microtransactions, uncomplet season pass), I advise you to wait for a sale.

6/10

------------------------

Pas un mauvais jeu, mais pas non plus un hit en puissance comme l'a été L4D.

J'ai surtout joué chasseur et bien qu'Evolve propose une ambiance de dingue et parfois de bonnes parties, je lui trouve 3 défauts majeurs :

- Un setting console : la plupart des armes/outils ne demande aucune précision à la visée. Un peu dommage pour un FPS.
- Manque de rythme dans les phases de traque. Le monstre possède tous les outils pour donner le tempo de la partie de la partie et s'amuser. Côté chasseur on se fait systématiquement balader avec nos jet-pack asthmatiques, même quand on connait bien la map. Assez pénible. Surtout, hors certaines compétences de traque, il n'y a pas grand chose à faire d'autre que d'appuyer sur Z et espace. L'univers, pourtant réussi, semble inutile, on l'ignore rapidement.
- Des combats coop trop orientés MOBA : les mauvais joueurs impactent plus la partie que les bons joueurs. Chaque perso est incomplet (manque de dégâts/impossibilité de capturer/impossibilité de soigner/difficulté à survivre), donc pas question de s'amuser en lonewolf ou espérer relever le niveau d'une équipe avec un skill solide comme dans un FPS multi classique. L'équipe sera toujours tirée vers le bas par le joueur le plus mauvais. Celui-ci flinguera régulièrement la partie en échouant son action de classe, nous laissant impuissants, spectateurs de la déchéance de l'équipe. Vraiment très frustrant.

Je passe sur l'interface horrible (5 min de loadings pour 10 minutes de partie) et le marketing dégeulasse (DLC Day one, microtransactions, season pass qui contient peu de choses), je vous conseille d'attendre une solde.

6/10

reviewText:
I played the Alpha, runned smoothly, loved the game, pre-purchased it. Then, I heard about the upcoming DLCs and how they were going to be additional monsters and hunters. That alone turned me off (and I'm going to explain why), so I asked for a refund. I played the Beta and suddenly the game was unplayable, stuck at 10FPS constantly when during the Alpha I played comfortably at 60FPS. What went wrong?

Regarding DLCs:
-A DLC has to be an addendum to a finished product. It ads a dessert to someone who finished the meal and would like some more.
- In any case it is not mashed potatoes, rice or veggies to try out instead of pasta. When the menu is set, it doesn't get changed!

What Evolve's DLC offer:
-They're not mappacks as not to split community. That is commendable, but I wouldn't mind AT ALL paying for that kind of DLC, as it adds a new playground to a fixed gameplay.
-The DLC offer different monsters/hunters, i.e. it offers different gameplay mechanics. How come is this not chipping away at the core game?

Turtle Rock's answer:
The DLC content is going to be completely new and has not been thought of in the base game, we're not removing any content from the base game (or something in those lines).

Me:
So you're saying that, for an assymetrical multiplayer game, you're going to be releasing a stream of gameplay changing content that will inevitably mess the fragile equilibrium of the game and not even give access to that content to the entire comunity?
Also, as advantages are bound to happen, I'm sure you will not nerf down DLC characters too much, I mean: it's realistic for you to want DLC's to have a selling argument. Right? If so, isn't your game turning out to be a pay-2-win, although I have to pay for the base game?

TR:
But you get to play against and with the people who have that content, you're not going to be separated from the comunity, even if you don't purchase the DLCs.

Me:
So you're telling me that the code for all the DLC content is going to be downloaded to my PC as well, as I need to see it in action on other players, and that I will have to pay for it to unlock? Well thanks for adding every so months a few gigabites of DLC download that I won't be even able to use unless I give you some money...


In the end this is my point of view:

I would have gladly payed the pre purchasing price and even a season pass/game combo if the DLC's wouldn't have been gameplay related, but this setup is a recipe for disaster and I don't want to be caught up in the mess that is going to be balancing the game at each new character addition. Plus in a year or even less there is going to be a deluxe package for 30 euros where I can get all the content at once with most of the bugs fixed as well.

So in the end, don't buy this game as long as the gameplay balancing hasn't been achieved, and this will last as long as they're adding characters...

reviewText:
Paid 80 bucks... regret...

3 hunters in each class, but some of them are plain useless, you could safely say about 1 in each of the classes are  completely useless in multiplayer (cept maybe the hunters, cos their strengths and weaknesses are pretty balanced... aka, they're all equally weak).

Overpowered wraith (too easy to get to 3, max out decoy, and if you can, find the 50% buff).

Tactics become pretty straight forward after a while for monsters, run, eat, hide, if oppos split up... ambush for free kill, if oppos stick, you will NEVER get caught -

Once you've played enough, game gets really repititive, and the GFX hardware demands are really high for this game for any level of smoothness.

Lack of critical number of players due to stupidly high entry costs (and hardward reqs) also means that currently, it takes a stupid amount of time for a game to begin, and they are rarely filled nowadays too.

Perhaps the best way to deal with the issues is to enable even lower quality gfx settings, more game balancing, and either one of the two - More content (because seriously, this game doesn't feel like what it's costing...), OR, reduce the DAMN PRICE.

There's just not enough players taking up this game to make the sole online element smooth.

reviewText:
Putting aside the greediness of 2K which in my opinion should be enough to warrant a boycott, the game is still incredibly underwhelming.  As many have pointed out on release there is a significant lack of content.  All maps are played in similar environments and at night time.

The other significant disappointing factor is it heavy reliance on hunters having headsets and a strong grasp of their team mates classes and their abilities. Your weakest player for whatever reason will be made painfully apparent very quickly.  This in turn puts the spotlight on the casual gamer significantly hindering its accessibility to the masses.  Even a competent random hunter teams are clinging on to be coherent and effective against a seasoned Monster.

Sadly many are walking away from the game after only 5-10 hours leaving the player base already dwindling.

Lastly in order for the Monsters to gain the upper hand against the hunters, they must evade them till they can reach stage 3.  Another words when your Hunter group isn't top notch you will spend 90% of the round trying to catch the monster.

In this games defence however,  if you have 5 mates all with headsets and online at the same time,  this game is fantastic,  with the 5th person being rotated to be the monster.

MAYBE. [/b]

reviewText:
I have played around 180 hours in this game.
That being said, I would have to agree with the majority of the reviews, this game is crap.
Not worth the money AT ALL.
The programing is terrible, the AI are mentally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.
Got so sick of the match system and douchery of people I switched to single player for a bit. The entire single player mode is BS. Monster always goes for the Medic first, not only does the monster incap the medic, it will sit there and kill him off right from the get go. It's like watching the same movie over and over. Start new game, trap monster, monster kills Medic first then so on.  It has happened in every game choice for single player. That is one of MANY issues I have with this game.
For the price, not worth it. I have played better free games than this.
I have played so many hours hoping that it gets better or that they fixed it, but it never happened.
The action is nice and all, but damn this game is repetitive. Basically what I am really trying to say, they should have waited another year before releasing. This game needs a ton of work..really wish there was a way to get my money back. Extremely disappointed in the final product, not to mention the money wasted. This would be better as a free to play game.

reviewText: Evolve was one of the coolest and most unique gaming experiences I had in and around 2015 but like most people my thrill for the game slowly died as the game presented numerous delays, unfulfilled potential and a lot of disappointed players. It goes without saying the Evolve has a brilliant style and unique game-play that me and ♥♥♥♥ loads of other people clearly adore, but every small packed game gets boring no matter how great it is. Players quickly got bored and eventually put the game aside and honestly it makes the game feel empty to this day. If you could go back in time to early 2015 then by all means get the game, but sadly it's too late for this dead game.\n\n6/10

reviewText:
Simply put, this is one of the best games I’ve ever played and I started back in the days of the old Sega Master System 2. It is not your standard FPS game and I think that is what catches many people out. Forget all the rubbish people spouted about DLC and the initial release marketing as this actually has zero impact on the game itself. All DLC is either cosmetic in nature (skins) or simply added content that plays within the same world as you. Far from hindering your experience or making it easier for one side or another, the only impact it has is add more variety of opponents and teammates, and that is only a good thing. Nothing is required to be bought other than the base game.

If you are not sure what to believe after reading things online, I can understand. The fact is that this game has a surprisingly steep learning curve and not everyone was ready for it when they made their first gameplay impressions. It has a lot more subtlety and nuance than you might think but it takes time to work these things out.  It’s not a game you can jump in, guns blazing, expecting an easy win. You really need to learn the strategy, but when you do, it can be an awesome experience.

Some things to remember are that the old lone wolf style of play just doesn’t work here unless you are keen to give the Monster a go. It is imperative as a Hunter to work as a team as the characters and classes are all very good at what they do, but cannot win the day by themselves. If you learn the roles each class needs to fill and support your teammates while they do their jobs then you’ll really enjoy yourself here. Definitely a game for people that enjoy teamwork.

I love real time strategy games like the Total War and Command & Conquer series. This game incorporates some of the strategy of these types of games and puts it into a first person shooter scenario. It’s hard to explain but if you can think strategy as well as point and shoot, then this game is perfect for you. Give it a go, try the different classes, see what you think and figure out what class gels with you the most.

At the end of the day, you need to make your own opinion. I can tell that it’s built by a developer that actually listens and actively involves its community. It continues to grow the content and add value at every turn, most of which is for free. Ignore the negative hype, and if you’re not sure then simply jump on the Turtle Rock Forums (https://www.turtlerockstudios.com/) and I'm sure you’ll figure it out for yourself. It is a great game to play, the community is open and passionate, and if you’re willing to put a bit of effort in to learning how to play your chosen role properly, then you will have a fantastic time. This game is definitely worth it.

reviewText:
Long review, bear with me. Will update when I feel like it.

Thanks to Daniel my pocket buddy for introducing me to the game, and Rohan from 2K Games in Singapore for giving us the chance to play it at the office.

----

After preview testing, Big Alpha, Closed Beta, the Monster Race retail edition... this game has not let me down yet. The graphics are as magnificent as any CryEngine product tends to do, although three stages of testing still leaves a few bugs around.

The most intense shooter I've played, where every game is completely different and can go either way - monster technique and hunter cooperation are a must if you want to stand a chance. No playable class is inferior, everyone is equally important, and I say that to the greatest extent that words allow. Engaging the hunters as a stage one monster is no guarantee of a loss, and neither is a stage three a win.

Gameplay is brutal for newcomers and there is no notable tutorial for each class; videos are token effort at best and grossly misleading at worst. Strongly recommended to play with at least one friend, preferably with three others in a full party with voice comms. If you do not work together, I assure you that you will lose to a monster of your peer. (In that vein, there is in fact a solo mode but with an AI monster and absolutely atrocious AI teammates I hope you are prepared to play it just for the mastery.)

----

I have not played in three months and have only just come back to semi-serious playtime since interest has been piqued over this weekend's 40%-off sale.

Most of the criticism the game has received comprises accusations of a high price point and day-one downloadable content"
date: conveniently omitting the fact that the overwhelming majority of said price consists of cosmetic skins for the hunters and monsters.\n\nStraight out of the box the vanilla game is playable and many meta teams - if that is your flavour of shooter - do not require additional hunters .Sure
recommended: you have to pay for a monster here and a hunter tier there but I haven't heard of anyone complain about non-essential content sold later in any other game either. And those are not day-one either
hoursPlayed: as anything after the first three tiers was released at least a month later and/or tied to pre-order bonuses and season pass.\n\nI will not even give the point about the state of the playerbase
voteText: since most out there are impressionable and ignorant
helpfulPercent: and would have been influenced by equally ignorant and scathing reviews of a game they barely put any hours into.\n\nWhat I will give is the state of the game: an extremely steep learning curve and a 100% mission-critical need for teamwork and decent level of skill. Good monsters will play by themselves and dunk on matchmade hunters; good hunters who inevitably have to solo queue will likely get a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ teammates and have to face off against aforementioned monster plus dunking. (This will demoralise anyone faint of heart
votesHelpful: and to find these people you just have to look at every other negative review aside from those already mentioned who ignore the cosmetic nature of DLC.)\n\nOn that note
votesTotal: competitive play is still going strong
votesFunny: with a proper ESL showing and Go4Evolve every weekend. Tune in to those tourneys to get a look at what you're missing."

reviewText:
UPDATED Sept 2015============================================
I have played every available test and free weekend of this game. Here are my opinions:

Cons:
- Progression system with weapon and ability leveling (mastery) that provides performance buffs
- No mods, modding support, or modding tools
- Unlockable hunters and monsters
- Unlockable gameplay-affecting perks
- Repetitive in gameplay and level design
- Post-game progression is so convoluted and lengthy it takes 5 minutes just to get through the endless parade of accolades
- Limited content
- Matchmaking has major problems with parties
- Slow matchmaking
- Competitive-only, no casual matchmaking
- 3 different ranking systems (mastery output stars, numbered XP ranks, and metal point categorization)
- Major balance problems with some characters and combinations
- Repeated audio cues that lack explanation as to what they mean
- Cannot play monster with your friends
- No dedicated servers
- Hunters and monsters are sold as DLC
- A lot of DLC for sale at high prices

Pros:
+ Beautiful
+ Play as a big boss monster
+ Singleplayer in addition to multiplayer
+ Well developed lore, environments, and people
+ Developer is still supporting the game
+ Characters have different things to contribute

Conclusion:
Evolve isn't going in the right direction. The developer is focusing on making their game an e-sport while ignoring fairness and variety. If you're the type of gamer who wants to see a badge or ribbon awarded every 15 seconds plus get stat bonuses over time then this is for you. If you prefer gameplay variety and a level-playing field this game is not for you.

Turtle Rock Studios and 2K could win my purchase by getting rid of the mastery system buffs and unlocking all hunters and monsters right from the start. They could also win my purchase by allowing mods so we can make our own maps, monsters, and hunters. These issues are why I have not purchased the game despite being hyped for it in the past.

ORIGINAL Feb 2015 Review=======================================
Avoid.

Has something called mastery stars" in which buff hunter weapons and tools as well as monster abilities. The buffs go up to 10% and must be unlocked through a Battlefield-like progression system. The mastery stars stack on top of perks and wildlife bonuses. This is not a skills-based competition -- it's an unlock-based competition. Those who have grinded out unlocks are given advantages. Mastery stars can also be acquired through a mobile companion app. You can play a match-3 game or purchase shortcuts.

Also has an unlock system that blocks 8 hunters and 2 monsters from players. You must complete challenges with the initial slate of 4 hunters and 1 monster to unlock other ones. Challenges are as typical as "do damage with the assault rifle" to tedious as "follow the AI dog
recommended: around." If you have a job and a life outside of gaming you will very quickly fall behind.\n\nFinally
hoursPlayed: be aware the DLC is very expensive for this game. Monsters are $15 and individual hunters are $7.50. The Hunting Season Pass is just a bundle of tier 5 hunters. It does not include tier 6 so I don't think it's what most people think of when they see the term "season pass" used. Skins are $3 each or up to $7 for a bundle. There is a significant amount of day-1 DLC. This is a $60

reviewText:
I played through the Alpha and Beta for this game and absolutely loved it.
At launch, the price tag was ridiculously high but the game was still a blast, and complaints about the game being pay-to-win were just made by people who didn't want to grind.

However, the game is finally pay-to-win because of the ridiculously overpowered fourth tier of hunters and underwhelming fourth monster. This game had it all: relatively easy entry point, high skill cap, varied gameplay mechanics based on character, flashy graphics, etc. Until these new guys have been hit with a behemoth-sized nerf, this game is as unplayable as it is unaffordable.

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying that I really do enjoy playing this game. It's a fun game. Teaming up with your friends to hunt the monster is a lot of fun. Playing as the monster against the humans is a lot of fun. The map design is good. The unlock system that encourages you to just play each character for a game or two before unlocking the next one is good. The gameplay is good. I played the alpha a few times and the beta, and had a blast every single time I played.

But I cannot in good conscience recommend this game.

$60 for the base game.
$80 for the base game + season pass. The season pass doesn't even come with all the content.
$100 for the Monster Race" edition
recommended: but still not all of the content.\n\nAnd another season pass
hoursPlayed:
for "season 2" has been announced.

This game is the worst example of nickel and diming from a major publisher I've ever seen. Part of me feels bad for the developers because they put out a fun game that I could see myself buying if it weren't for this ridiculous amount of DLC being torn from the main game and released seperately at exorbitant prices.

If you spend $60 on the base game
